div.p: A DECLARACION of the ſtate, wherin all heretikes dooe leade their liues: And alſo of their continuall indeuer, and propre fruictes, which beginneth in the .38. chapiter, and ſo to thende of the woorke

q.p: Eſt via, quae videtur homini recta, et nouiſſima eius ducunt ad mortem.

div.p: There is a waie, whiche ſemeth to a man ſtreight, and yet the endes therof leaden to perdicion.

div.head: To the readers.
div.p:
WE'L diſpoſed and good chriſten readers, ſo it is, that about. xvii. or xviii. yeres paſt, I beganne to write ageinſt Frithes booke which he made ageinſt the veritee of the holy ſacrament of the Altare: And I beeing then, where a print was in vſe and occupacion, procuryng the ſame for the puttinge foorthe of that I did intende, by that tyme ii. or iii. chapiters of that I had written was printed for aſſaie, to ſee how the printer wolde and coulde ſet it forth, I fell ſo ſicke, that I was fayne to gette me to London, for the remedy and helpe of mine infirmitee, where I laie a longe tyme in greate daunger. And before I was able to go abrode, the printer (as I ſuppoſe for lacke of worke) beeing where he myght come by my ſcrowes and papers, printed vp the reſte of that I had doone, after ſuche ſorte, as he coulde pike it out of my firſt draught therof. And ſent me the booke, before I was able (as I ſayd) to come out of my chamber: wherin, he diſpleaſed me ſo muche, that I did not intende to go any farder with the matter. And that not only becauſe he did ſo muche with out my conſent, but alſo ſpecially becauſe it was doone, before I had peruſed and dewly examined that I had written, as that and other like thinges, dothe alway require. For I thinke there be no writer, that willeth any matter of weight to paſſe his handes, before he hath made with hym ſelfe, vpon the firſt drawght, a dew examinacion therof, wherby, he may perceiue and ſee, whether it ſhulde nede, either any addicion, or diminucion, or
els alteracion, and better diſpoſicion of order, wherby the worke maie bee the more compendious, and of leſſe difficultee or tediouſnes vnto the readers. For my intention was (if I might than haue had tyme) to digeſte, diſpoſe and order the matter after this ſort: Firſt, that it ſhulde appere by it ſelfe, what the ſtate of an heretike is, and in what condicion he leadeth his life. And after that, what maner of foundacion it is, where vpon Frith (as he ſaieth) doth builde and frame his purpoſe. Thirdly, that it ſhulde appered alſo by it ſelfe, how falſely and fooliſhely he dothe take, not only the holy ſcripture, but alſo the olde holy fathers and auncient doctours of the catholike church, whom he boſteth ſo muche to make for him, not withſtandinge that thei are all directly ageinſt hym. Fourthly, what his reaſons and argumentes are, which he pretendeth to be no leſſe then inuincible, and yet ſo falſe and fooliſhe in dede, as are not worthe the heringe. Fiftly, what is to be ſayd vnto hym and all his adherentes, in that they holde, that one bodie can not bee in two places at once. Sixtly, that the poſſibilitee therof (whan they haue all doone) is yet probable, by very naturall reaſon, one principle graunted, whiche no reaſonable man can denie. This was mine order, whiche I did intende. And although I were then diſapointed therof, thorowe the haſtie raſhnes of the printer (as is aforeſaid) intending therfore to go no farder with all, litle thinking then, that the venim of Frithes booke wolde haue ſpredde ſo farre abrode, as the lamentable experience therof doth preſently declare: yet now vpon that, and other ſuche vrgent occaſions, as I haue ſince and dayly do ſee, I haue returned vnto my firſt purpoſe ageyn, and ſo gone forwarde with all, that I haue newe
written all that I wrote before, with ſuch alteracion therof, as the tyme and change of thinges hath ſynce miniſtred great, and worthie occaſion. Wherfore moſte gentill readers, vſe therin your indifferent iudgement, and impute of my labour no more vnto me, but only a mocion or occaſion geuen vnto other, that can dooe much better. And thus I committe you to god.

list.item: AN introduction of the matter. Cap. 1.
That no heretike can knowe, or ſo muche as beleue or thinke, that he is an heretike. Cap. 2.
The cauſe why, that an heretike can not knowe, beleue, or thinke that he is an heretike. Cap. 3.
¶ What is the cauſe that hereſie is ſo ſildome or neuer amended. Cap. 4.
That theſe wordes of the prophet (The foliſh man ſayd in his herte, There is no God, are well and trewly vnderſtande of euery heretike. Cap. 5.
Whether the trewthe of all the whole feithe, be conteined in euery ſingular article or no. Cap. 6.

That the trewthe of the feithe is no more in the whole, than in the leaſt parte of it, nor no leſſe in the leaſt parte, than in all the whole, nor none other in any one parte of it than in any other, or in them all together. Cap. 7.
That the trewthe and the thynge, wherin it is, are not bothe one. And therfore although the thynges differ, yet the trewthe in them diffreth not. Cap. 8.
That trewthe is inalterable, and that all heretikes are deceiued, not only in thoſe articles, whiche thei directly denie, but alſo in thoſe, whiche thei ſeme and thynke thei graunt. Cap. 9.

That ſuche difference is betwene the trewthe of one
article, and the trewthe of an other, as ther is betwene Iohn, the name of one man, and Iohn the name of an other. Cap. 10.
That ther is but one trewthe in all and euery maner of thynge. And therfore what nede it to be ſought in ſo many thynges as it is, whan the ſekers therof haue it all redy in ſome thynge. Cap. 11.
That trewthe, whiche is not diuerſe, doth diuerſly behaue it ſelfe in diuers thynges, and is more expedient to be had in ſome thynges than in ſome. Cap. 12.
What is to bee vnderſtande of theſe wordes of chriſte, I am the waie, trewthe, and lyfe. Cap. 13.
When theſe three, The waie, trewthe and life, are all but one trewth, why thei are ſo put, as thoughe thei were otherwiſe. Cap. 14.
That more or leſſe of trewthe, dothe muche differ from more or leſſe than trewthe. Cap. 15.
That he whiche ſeketh after trewthe, ſeketh for none other, but that he hath all redie, and yet laboureth not in vaine, nor without nede. Cap. 16.
If one trewthe bee indifferent to bothe the colours of blacke and white, why maie not the blacke be trewly called white, and the white blacke. Cap. 17.
That the ſcripture dooeth ſpeake ofte tymes after the commune maner of them, to whom it ſpeaketh, and not after the proper perfection of the thynge, wherof it ſpeaketh. Cap. 18.

That if there be but one trewthe in all and euery thyng, it ſemeth to folowe, that who ſo euer denieth the trewthe of any thynge, muſt nedes be an heretike, becauſe he denieth the ſame trewthe that an heretike dothe. Cap. 19.
That trewth byndeth not like in all thynges: and how a man maie denie the ſame trewthe whiche an heretike dooeth, and yet be no heretike at all. Cap. 20.
The cauſe why that the deniall of one article dooeth more hynder and leſe, than the confeſſion and graunt of all the reſte, is able to get or ſaue. Cap. 21.

That who ſo euer denieth Chriſte, as the Turkes doe, to bee verie god, denieth hym alſo therin, to be a veraie
man. Cap. 22.
Howe the propre ſignificacion of this name Ieſus, and this name Chriſt, doo the differ. Cap. 23.
That it differeth muche to denie a thynge to be the ſame that it is, and to denie it to be in this or that, or here or there. Cap. 24.
That the vnitee of any thynge can not bee denied without the deniall of what ſo euer is included or conteined therin. Cap. 25.
That the vnitee of Chriſtes perſon can not bee denied, without the denial, bothe of his deitee, and alſo of his humanitee. Cap. 26.
After what ſorte diuerſe heretikes haue ſuffered death in certayn poyntes of the feythe. Cap. 27.
That no credence is to be geuen to their iudgement, whiche thinke an heretike ſo erre in no more of the feithe, but in thoſe pointes, whiche he doth directly denie. C. 28.
Whether he that ſaieth in his herte, There is no God, denieth god directly, or conſequently, and whether a man maie thynke that he hym ſelfe is not ware of, or no. Capitulo. 29.
That to denie god but conſequently, is proued by ſcripture to be no leſſe euill, than it is, to denie hym directly. Capitulo. 30.
Howe it maie ſtande together, that all heretikes denieth the trewth of all the whole feithe, and yet graunt and confeſſe ſo many articles therof as thei dooe. Cap. 31.
That an heretikes graunt of the trewthe, is not like an other mannes graunt therof. Cap. 32.
That a directe graunt can not ſtande with a deniall conſequent. Cap. 33.
That before god, there is no differrence betwene an antecedent and a conſequent, that is to ſaie betwene before and after. Cap. 34.
That farre wors is he, that directly denieth but ſome parte of the feithe, than is he that directly denieth all together. Cap. 35.

That the trewthe of Chriſte is no oftener denied in many articles, than in one alone: and therfore no more
faute is the one than the other. Cap. 36.
That he whiche denieth Chriſte directly, dooeth it no more ware and wittyngly, then dooeth he, whiche denieth hym but conſequently. Cap. 37.
What the continewall indeuor of heretikes is, and what ſucceſſe thei haue therin. Cap. 38.
That heretikes doe good, and therof take hurte. more ouer howe ſtrangely thei worke, and after what ſpirite. Cap. 39.
That although heretikes dooe no miracles, yet thei doe ſhewe meruailes. Cap. 40.
That heretikes taunte vs with commune fautes, to thintente thei might therby cloke and hide the reſte of their owne propre and ſpeciall fautes. Cap. 41.
What fruictes thei be, whiche Chriſt our ſauior doothe teache vs to knowe heretikes by. Cap. 42.
Whether a generall deſcripcion of heretikes can diſpleaſe heretikes or no. Cap. 43.

sp.speaker: CCATHOLICVS,
sp.p: Hearke I ſaie cuntreman, a worde with the.

sp.speaker: HERETICVS.
sp.p: Speake ye to me ſir?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: What queſtion is that, where there is none, but hou and I?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: What woulde ye with me?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Shall I tell the?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: At your pleaſure.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Trewly, When I ſawe the cumminge this wai alone, thou madeſt me therwith verie gladde.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Doutles becauſe I haue bene a greate while verie deſirous to talke with the.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: With me ſir?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Ye with the. And yet coulde I neuer finde the tyme and place, but by reaſon of companie, or one thinge or other, there was alwaie ſome occaſion to interrupt and let my purpoſe? Therfore now, while it hath chaunced vs, thus luckily (as I hope) here to meete in this quiete place, where there be no ſuche impedimentes, but that we maie ſaie, thou to me, and I to the, what ſo euer ſhall like vs beſt: I ſhall for my part (if thou wilt abide and harken well to me) ſhowe the ſome thinges, perchaunce not a litle beyonde thine expectacion.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Sir of ſuch thinges, wolde I be gladde to here. But yet I meruaile greatly, that ye ſhoulde be ſo deſirous to talke with me. For I ſuppoſe ye knowe me not.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Yes well enoughe, by ſight and here ſaie.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: why, what haue ye herde of me?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
In verie dede, I will not longe hide it from the. How be it thou knoweſt, that deliberacion geueth ſomtime, a great occaſion of wiſdome: where as haſte doeth oft times the contrarie. For that thinge, whiche a man doothe ſome
tyme iudge, well and mete to be doone or ſaide at the firſte, by furder leiſure and deliberacion taken therin, he perceiueth at length to be farre otherwiſe, whiche I do now finde by experience.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: How ſo?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: I ſhall tell the. When I was firſt moued and be came deſirous to commune & talke with the (letted hitherto as I haue ſhowed the) I did then intēd to haue aſked of the a certaine queſtion, which I perceue now (by reaſon of a more deliberate conſideration conceiued ſince in the meane ſpace) had ben but very ſuperfluous and to no purpoſe.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: CAHT.
sp.p: what auaileth it, to aſke a queſtion of him, which can not tell the trewthe therof?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Thinke ye that in me?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Ye trewly.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Why, what is the queſtion?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: I haue tolde the a cauſe why, it were but in vayne to ſhow the.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: yet I pray you, ſince ye haue gone ſo farre with all, let me here it, and it were but for my fantaſie.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: So maiſt thou dooe and neuer the nere. How be it I will not ſticke with the, for more then that. And therfore the queſtion is this, I had thought than, to haue aſked the, whether thou be an heretike or not.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: That is a ſtraunge queſtion to me, but yet neuertheleſſe, doo you thinke that I can not tell the trewth therof?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: I thinke ſo in dede.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Then who can dooe it, if I can not, ſpecially when it towcheth me onely, and no man els?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: yet who ſo euer can, ſure it is that thou canneſt not.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: why ſo?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Becauſe ther is no heretike, that can tell whether he be an heretike or not.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: A ſir, well concluded. For now I perceue ye take me for an heretike.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
I ſaie
not ſo. But yet for ſo muche as I haue herde the often reported, to be an excedyng great fauourer and defender of Frith, and fayne wolde knowe the crewthe therof, thinkyng (at the firſte) that no man coulde tell me better then thou thy ſelfe: I thought therfore then, to haue aſked the queſtion of the, and of no man els. But vpon farder conſideracion therof had, becauſe I nowe finde no man more, nor yet ſo muche vnable, to anſwere the queſtion as thou art in dede: I therfore thought to paſſe it ouer, and not to trouble the with all, at this tyme.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Ye but coulde ye none other wiſe inquere of me, whether I were a fauourer of Frith or not, but to aſke me, whether I be an heretike or not?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: That is no matter, for all is one.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: Then can I gather no leſſe of your ſaiynge, but that ye take (at the leaſt) Frith or me, For an heretike, or els bothe.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: In dede thou haſt hit me therin, with ſuche a trewth, as I am not able to auoide.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: Well ſyr, I will be plaine with you, how ſo euer ye take it, Frith was a man, whom I loued with all my herte, and ſhall doe while I liue.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: I loue the, for that, neuer the better.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: And I loue my ſelfe neuer the worſe.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Thou canneſt not tell that. For the ſcripture dooeth ſaie.Pſal. 10. Qui diligit iniquitatem, odit animam ſuam. He that loueth iniquitee, hath his own ſoule. And yet many a one, that ſo doth, thinketh thē ſelues to loue their own ſoules well enough. But neuertheleſſe, credence is to be geuē to the ſcripture, what ſo euer thei ſaie or thinke.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Thinke you, that I loue iniquitee, in that I loue Frith?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: I thinke ſo in dede, if thou loue him (as I beleue thou doeſt) for his hereticall opinions.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p:
A ha, then it is playne enough, that ye take hym for an heretike.
For what maketh an heretike but heriticall opinions?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Nothynge els, that I knowe.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Therfore fayne wolde I here of you, what heriticall opinions ye can fynde in hym, to proue hym an heretike by.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Before we come to that, let vs firſte (as I thynke it beſte) ſerche, trie, and proue, what the ſtate of an heretike is. That vpon the knowlage of what caſe or condicion he liueth in, we maie the better perceiue, what he is, and conſequently whether Frith were any ſuche or no.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: With that I am content.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Therfore, the firſte notable thynge, that I fynde in the ſtate of an heretike is this, that it is not poſſible for hym to knowe, that he is an heretike.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: I meruaile greatly what ſhuld moue you to be of that opinion.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Trewly I haue therein, none opinion at all.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Why than do ye ſpeake it?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Not becauſe of any opiniō therof, but becauſe I do certainly know it, which paſſeth opinion. And therfore, becauſe thou thinkeſt the matter ſo ſtraynge, I wyll adde vnto it this much more, that there is none of them, that dooeth or can ſo muche as beleue or thinke, that him ſelfe is an heretike.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: What not ſo muche as beleue or thinke it?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: No trewly.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: It is to farre againſt reaſon, for any man maie thinke, what ſo euer he luſte, whether it be trewe or falſe.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
Thou art therin muche deceiued. For all though, to thinke and to beleue may be taken all one, yet to thinke & to imagine, are not both one. For thou maiſt imagine, all ſteples and towers to haue ſpronge out of the grounde as trees doe: and alſo euery thynge to be otherwiſe then thou knoweſt it is, if thou wilt. But yet thou canſt not ſo thinke or beleue, although thou woldeſt neuer ſo fayne. For thou canſt not (if thou
marke it well) beleue or thinke any thyng, againſt thine owne knowlage. But yet for all that, Thou maieſt ſo imagine alwaie at thy pleaſure. Whereof it appereth playne, that imaginacion is one, and thinkynge or beleuyng is an other. Therfore although an heretike maie imagine hym ſelfe to be an heretike, (as perchaunce he will not) yet (as I ſaide) he can neuer (for all that) ſo beleue or thinke, although he wolde. Muche leſſe then, is he able to knowe it. And who therfore wolde aſke hym the queſtion?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Yet maie he as ſoone beleue and alſo knowe that, as I can beleue you, when ye ſaie that he can not, excepte ye ſhewe me ſome good reaſon why.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Thou muſt nedes graunt me this, that there is no man an heretike, but becauſe he beleueth amiſſe in ſome parte of the faithe.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: That is trewe.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Therfore if he coulde beleue that he were an heretike, than might he beleue that thynge, whiche he doeth not beleue, and that bothe at once, whiche were impoſſible. For it is not poſſible for a man to beleue any thynge, to be euen than any other wiſe than he doeth beleue it is. As thus, ſuppoſe one ſo wicked, as to beleue our ſauior Chriſt to be but onely a pure man, and not alſo very god: as in tyme paſte, ſome heretikes did.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: What of that?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
Euen this, if he that ſo beleueth, coulde beleue, that he were therin (as he is in dede) an heretike, he ſhulde than beleue and thinke, that he beleued therin amiſſe. Wherfore, if he did beleue
and thinke, that he beleueth amiſſe, in that he beleueth our ſauiour Chriſte to be but onely a man, plaine it is, that he ſhulde therin beleue hym to be both god and man, whan he doth thinke hym ſelfe to beleue amiſſe, beleuyng the contrarie: and ſo ſhuld he beleue & not beleue one thynge both at once, which (as I ſaide) is impoſſible. wherfore it muſt nedes folowe, that an heretike can neuer beleue or thinke, that hym ſelfe is an heretike.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Syr I doe nowe ſomewhat perceiue the thynge my ſelfe. For if I be nat deceiued, it is lyke, as if you did beleue and verily thinke the great Turke to be now here in Englande in dede, it were not poſſible for you to beleue, that ye beleue therin amiſſe, whan your beleue is vtterly, that it is euen ſo. For whan ye beleue, that he is in Englande, if ye coulde beleue, that ye beleued therin amiſſe, than might ye beleue, that he were not in Englande, whan ye beleue hym to be in it, and ſo ſhulde ye beleue and not beleue one thynge (as ye ſaide) bothe at once, whiche I perceiue were agaynſt all reaſon and trewthe.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Doutles thou ſpeakeſt herein veray well to the purpoſe, and that perchaunce wolde yet more playnly appere by this. Beleue is ſuche a thynge, as can neuer wittyngly be deceiued, for as ſoone as thou dooeſt thynke, that thou beleueſt in any thynge amiſſe, furthe with in the ſame inſtant thy beleue therin is clene altered and chainged, and is not the ſame that it was before. And therfore becauſe hereſie is none other, but in ſome parte of the faithe, a miſſebeleue, and a miſſe beleue is not poſſible to be perceiued of hym, in whom it is: it muſt nedes folowe, that no heretike can beleue or thinke that hym ſelfe is an heretike, becauſe he can not beleue or thinke, that he beleueth therin amiſſe.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Sir this is nowe farre from the nede of any more probacion.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Ye but yet, thou ſeeſt not all.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: If thou marke it well, this concluſion maie take awaie no ſmall wonder from many men.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: what wonder is that?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
Trewly what ſhuld be the cauſe of the rare and ſeldome amendment of heretikes: wherof partly hath ſpronge this comune opinion, that hereſie, franſie, & ieloſie be three diſeaſes incurable: Not becauſe thei be al vtterly ſo in dede, but becauſe they be ſo ſildome ſene, to bee throughly cured & healed ageyne. And ſpecially of hereſy, what wonder is it, although it be ſeldome or neuer forſaken & amended? whā it is (as thou haſt now herde) to euery heretike (as to one in a continuall traunce) vtterly vnknowne & incredible, that him ſelfe is any thinge therwith infected. for he thinketh verily, yt he is in the ſtreight waie, not remembringe therof, what the holy ſcripture ſaieth, Eſt via que videtur homini recta, Prou. 16. & nouiſſima eius ducunt ad mortem, That is to ſaie, There is a waie whiche ſeemeth to a man ſtreighte, and yet the endes therof leadeth hym to perdicion. And therfore who can expell and put that awaie from him, whiche he can not beleue that euer it came nere hym? who can deſyre to be healed of that infirmitee, wherwith he can not thynke that euer he was diſeaſed? or who can be willing for to amende, wherin he can not ſo muche as thinke, that euer he did offende, ſpecially whan we may dayly ſee the amendemet of manifeſte euils, very ſeldome or neuer brought to paſſe in ſome, whan they bothe beleue and knowe them ſelues to be infected with them. Yet muche eaſier it is (be it neuer ſo harde) to leaue and amende
that is perceiued and knowne amiſſe, than it is (be it neuer ſo eaſie) to auoide and forſake that, which is cleane hid, vnknowne, and incredible. Who therfore, or what can purge, cure, or heale this moſt perelous and inſenſible ſicknes, but only the great mercie of him, which of a blinde and crewell perſecutour, made a moſte pacient and excellent preacher?Act. 9. but how ſhuld his moſt mercifull medicine be opteined, where it is neuer deſired? and howe can it be deſired, where the cauſe why, nother is, nor can be perceiued? By this therfore thou maiſte haue ſome vnderſtanding of the lamentable ſtate of an heretike, who of all men is in moſte daunger: and yet fardeſt of, from all good remedie, helpe, or ſuccour.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Haue you any worſe to ſaie of him than that.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: In dede I haue more, whether it be worſe or no, I will referre that to thy iudgement, if thou wilt tarry the hearing therof.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Yes ſir that will I doe, if this daie will ſerue the turne.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Then what wilt thou ſaie, if this felowe be he, whom the prophet doeth meane, where he ſaith:Pſal. 13. Dixit inſipiens in cordo ſuo, non eſt deus, The fooliſhe man ſaide in his herte, there is no god?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: What heretike can we finde or reade of, that euer ſaide in his herte there is no god.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Recken whiche of them thou wilt, thou canſte not chooſe amiſſe.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: By that, ye will make it euery one of theim.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: I will not make it, but ſo it is for all that.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: It were harde to make me beleue it.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
The due order of inuincible reaſon, ſhall bringe the to it, if thou wilt ſtande to that: For the probacion
of the thinge, is eaſie to be made, ye and (ſoberly herde) more eaſie to be vnderſtande.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: When I here it, I will tell you more of my minde.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Of this thou art aſſured by the ſcripture before alleged, that ſome there be, which ſaie in the he • te, there is no god.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: That I dooe now take to be trew, For els the ſcripture wolde not ſpeake therof, as it dooeth.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Therfore what other thinge is it, to ſaie in the herte, there is no god, then euen ſecretly in the herte, to denie god?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: I take that to be all one.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: If thou ſo doo, thou takeſt it right. And therfore becauſe it is ſure, that Chriſt is very god him ſelfe, it muſte nedes folow, that he, whiche denieth god in his herte, denieth Chriſte.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Of that concluſion, faine wolde I here ſome better proſe.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: An other thou maieſt, but no better.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Then an other.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: That ſhalbe this. Thou knoweſt (I ſuppoſe) that Chriſt in diuerſe places of ſcripture,1. Pet. 1. is declared to be (as he is in dede) the very ſonne, of god the father?1. Ioan. 1.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: That is trew.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: And euen ſo is this, that he, which denieth god, denieth any ſuche father, for that which is not, can be no father. And he that denieth any ſuche father, denieth alſo therin any ſuche ſonne. For no ſuche ſonne can be, of no ſuche father, nor no ſuche father can be, of no god. And therfore of no ſuche father and no ſuche ſon, muſt nedes folowe no Chriſte, for he were not Chriſte, if he were not the verie and onely ſonne of god, whom in the hert, (as the ſcripture ſaith) the fooliſh felowe denieth. And therfore conſequently euen Chriſte alſo.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Now I perceue and graunt the ſame.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
Then furder ſaieth the dew order of reaſon this, that he, whiche denieth Chriſt, denieth the verie trewth of all his whole
feith.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Perchaunce that maie be trewe.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: There is no chaunce in that point, for it is more playne, then ſhall nede any farder probacion. And therfore he, which denieth the trewth of all the whole faithe, denieth therin ſome part therof, or els he could not deni the whole.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: That is out of all queſtion.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Then muſte this folowe, that he whiche denieth the trewth of any parte of the faith, denieth therin the trewthe of all the whole.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: That I muſt nedes denie, becauſe it folowith not. for although this muſt nedes folowe, that he which denieth the trewth of all the whole, denieth therin ſome parte therof, yet (of the other ſide) it is not poſſible for this to folowe, that he whiche denieth ſome part therof, denieth therin the trewth of all together. for theſe two latter propoſicions, can neuer be conuertible.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: what meaneſt thou, by propoſicions conuertible?

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: Two ſaienges, wherof eache muſte nedes folowe other, put before or behinde, which of them ye will.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: And doeſt thou thinke, that theſe two, be none of them?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: I thynke ſo.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Thou arte therin deceiued: For they be conuertible in dede, and ſo are all the reſte that went before, wherof theſe two, doo iuſtly folowe. And that ſhalt thou ſee ſtreight, for I will go backward with them again, and begin with this, whiche thou ſhalt not denie: who ſo euer is an heretike, he denieth ſome parte of the faith at the leaſte.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: That is trewe. for els he were no heretike at all.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: And who ſo euer denieth any part of the faith, denieth therin the trewth therof.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p:
I muſte
nedes graunt that alſo.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: And who ſo euer denieth the trewth of any part of the faithe, denieth therin the trewthe of all the whole.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: That I muſte and will (as I ſaide) vtterly denie.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Then muſte I proue it.

sp.speaker: HERET.
sp.p: Yea ſir if ye can: but I thinke it will be a good while firſte.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Then it ſhall be longe of the. For if all the trewthe, of all the whole feith be conteined in euery parte therof, who can auoide this, but he that denieth any parte therof, denieth therin, the trewthe of all the whole.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Ye ſyr if it be ſo, but firſte proue, that it is ſo, And then afterwarde cōclude as ye may.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: It ſhall nede no very great profe, after a certaine declaration made, of ſuche three thynges, as I ſhall ſhewe the.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Whiche be thoſe?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: The firſte is, what is more then trewthe. The ſeconde is, what is leſſe then trewthe. The thirde is, what is other then trewthe. Theſe three, that is to witte, more then trewthe, leſſe then trewthe, and other then trewthe, are all and eache of them, euen as farre from trewthe, as trewthe it ſelfe is from no trewthe: whiche be directe contraries.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: How ſhall this appere?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Uery well and plaine enough. For perticularly, to beginne with the firſt, of this we maie be well aſſured, that trewthe can be no more then trewthe.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: That I muſte nedes graunte.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Thou canſt doe no leſſe. And therfore when trewthe can be no more then trewthe, it muſte nedes folowe, that more then trewthe can be no trewthe.

sp.speaker: HERETIC.
sp.p: To that I aſſente alſo.

sp.speaker: CATHOLICVS.
sp.p:
Then ſecundarily, we bee
likewiſe aſſured of this, that trewthe can be no leſſe then trewthe.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: That is more playne, then can be denied.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Therfore whan trewth can be no leſſe then trewth: as plaine it is, that leſſe then trewth, can be no trewthe nother.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: To that I muſte nedes agree.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Then thirdly we maie not doubte, that trewth can be any other then trewth.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: That is out of all queſtion.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Therfore when trewthe can be none other than trewth, doth it not therfore iuſtly folowe, that other then trewthe, can be no trewthe?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Well ſyr, all this hitherto, I wyll not denie.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
Then to the purpoſe, and as touchyng the firſt, if the trewthe of the whole feithe, were any more, then the trewthe of the leaſt parte of it, then were it more then trewthe. For the trewthe of the leaſte parte is trewthe, and trewe to be more then trewthe, is all ready proued impoſſible. Wherfore the trewthe of the whole feith, can be no more, then the trewth of the leſt parte of it. Agein, for the ſeconde, by lyke reaſon, if the trewthe of the leaſt parte of it, were any leſſe, then the trewthe of the whole feithe, then were it leſſe then trewthe. For the trewthe of the whole, is trewthe: but trewthe to bee leſſe then trewthe, is well knowne can neuer bee. Therfore the trewthe of the leaſt parte of the feithe, is no leſſe, then the trewthe of all the whole. Now thirdly, if the trewthe of any one parte, were not the very ſame, but an other, then the trewthe of any other parte: then were it an other then trewth. For the trewth of any other parte is trewth, and trewth to be any other then trewth, is ſcant imaginable. Wherfore there can be none other trewthe, in any one parte of the feithe, than there is in any of the other, or in all the reſte together. Therfore becauſe the deniall
of any one parte of the feithe, is none other but the deniall of the trewthe therof. And whan there is no more, no leſſe, nor none other trewthe in all the whole feithe, then is in euery ſingular parte therof: it muſte nedes folowe, that who ſo euer denieth any parte of the feithe, denieth therin the trewthe of all the whole. And ciere it is, that he whiche denieth the trewthe of all the whole feithe, denieth Chriſte: And he that denieth Chriſte, denieth god. And thus doth euery heretike with out faile. Wherfore of euery one of theim all, theſe woordes of the prophet, The fooliſhe felowe ſaide in his herte, there is no god, maie well and trewly be verified.Pſal. 13.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Syr I beleue this matter wyll yet trouble vs bothe, ere we parte, for all this.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Becauſe there cometh nowe to my remembrance, ſuche, and ſo many thynges to the contrarie, as maketh me thinke, that all this can not holde.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
Then thou haſte but a ſclender wit, or a fickell mynde, that will ſo quickly be moued, or with any thyng allured, from ſo well approued trewthe, as this is. Thou mighteſt rather haue ſaide, that there cometh many thingꝭ to thy remembrance, whiche cauſeth the to maruell, howe thei with this can agree together: becauſe there is no trewth in any one thynge, that can be againſt the trewth of any other. For trewth againſt trewth, is no more to ſaie, but trewthe ageinſt it ſelfe, whiche is not poſſible. Therfore if theſe thynges, whiche nowe ſo cometh (as thou ſaieſt) to thy remembrance be trewe, doubtles they with this, maie ioigne and agree together well enough, although thy knowlage can not ſee how. Of thother ſide,
if thei be not trewe, thei muſt be reiected and refuſed: becauſe this, by them or any other like, can not be auoided. Wherfore to exclude all maner of tergiuerſacion herein to come, let this, whiche is (as thou haſt herde) ſo dewly proued all redie, be fully agreed and ſtabliſhed betwene vs in the meane tyme, as a moſt ſure truthe and grounde to reſte vpon: or at the leaſte, till thou haſt founde ſome good cauſe why, it ought not ſo to be taken. which I am ſure thou canſt not dooe. And therfore, let me now here what thynges thoſe be, whiche moueth me to the contrarie.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Syr I will tell you. And firſte for example, the reſurrection of Chriſte, ye knowe is one parte of the feithe, and thaſcenſion is an other.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: All that is playne.

sp.speaker: HERET.
sp.p: Then, if the veray ſame trewth, no more, no leſſe, nor none other, were in the one article that is in the other, it muſte nedes folowe, that the reſurrection and the aſcencion ſhulde bee bothe one.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Howe ſo?

sp.speaker: HERET.
sp.p: Ye wyll not denie, but when I ſaie Chriſte roſe from death to lyfe, I ſaie trewthe.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: What els?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: And when you ſaie, that he aſcended, you ſaie truthe likewiſe.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Agreed.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Then if theſe bee not two diſtincte truthes, but are bothe one, ſo that the one is none other, but euen the very ſame that the other is, then ſaie you the very ſame that I doe. And I the verie ſame that you dooe.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
Ye but what ſame is that? I graunte, I ſaie the ſame trewthe, that thou doeſt: but yet not the ſame thyng, wherin the ſame truth is. But thou takeſt the trewthe (I perceiue) & the thynges, wherin it is, to be all one. And therfore becauſe the thinges differ, thou thinkeſt the trewthe in them to differ likewiſe, which is not ſo: for if the trewthe of the reſurrection
were not the ſame, but an other then the trewthe of the aſcenſion, it ſhulde be an other then trewthe: And trewth to be an other then trewthe, I tolde the before can neuer be. For an other then trewth, is no trewth. Wherfore, ſith it can not be an other, it muſte nedes be the ſame. And therfore who ſo euer denieth the trewthe of the one article, denieth therin the trewth of the other. And ſo (as I ſaide) of all together.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Yet is it ſtraunge to me, that one trewthe, whiche hath in it (as ye ſaie) no difference at all, ſhulde be in bothe tharticles, whiche haue a difference.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: And well ſpoken, for euen ſo ſtraunge it is, as the onely truthe of the reſurrection, whiche hath no difference, is in all trewe Chriſten hertꝭ at once, whiche haue a difference, and that of many thouſandes mo then we can tell. Therfore wilt thou ſaie, that the trewth therof, whiche is in one herte, is not the ſame in eache of the reſte, becauſe thei are ſo many and diuerſe? Dooeſt thou not knowe, that one thinge maie be comunely knowne of thouſandes at once?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Yes that is plaine.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: And nothynge can bee knowne, but by the trewth therof.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: I graunte the ſame.

sp.speaker: CAHT.
sp.p: Then it muſt nedes folowe, that the ſame one trewth, maie be in a thouſande heades at once. And therfore why not one trewthe, in many articles at once likewiſe?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p:
Ye but ſir, ye muſte conſider, that althoughe this one trewthe of the reſurrection, bee in your heade and mine bothe: yet it is not the trewthe of your head, nor of mine nother, but of an other thynge. And therfore becauſe (of and in) are two thinges, whiche maketh no litle difference, I ſaie, the trewthe of the reſurrection, allthoughe it bee in your heade and myne, as it is in many thouſandes
mo, yet it is not the trewthe of your head or mine, or of anie other beſide, but of that ſame one article only, and of none other. for although the trewth of one thing maie be in an other, yet it can not be the trewth of an other.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
In dede thy talke renneth from one thinge to an other, for when our purpoſe in this caſe, is no more but to proue the ſame trewth to be in one arcicle, that is in an other, and ſo in the reſt of them all together, ſtreight thou leapeſt from the onely being of the trewth, vnto the perteinyng or belonging therof: as thoughe we ſought, wherof the trewth ſhulde be, and not, whether the being therof in diuerſe thinges at once, maketh in, or of it ſelfe, any diuerſitee or difference, or no: when that is herein our purpoſe, and nothing els: vnto the whiche, I adde alſo this, that trewth, wherin or wherof, ſo euer it be, is yet no more nor leſſe, nor none other, then trewth, without any maner of diuerſitee: for it is not but one pure ſingle, ſimple, & indiuiſible thing, of this nature & propertee, that although there be nothing, whiche dooeth not perticipate the ſame, yet the numeroſitee or bigneſſe of thinges, wherin it is, (be they neuer ſo many or greate) can not make it any mo, or more: Nor the paucitee or littelnes of thinges, any fewer, or leſſe. Nor yet the diuerſitee or alteracion of thinges, any other or otherwiſe, but euen one and the ſame trewth ſtille, as euery where it is, and alway hath bene, and euer ſhall. Therfore, who ſo euer denieth a part of that, which hath no partes (as the trewth it ſelfe hath not in dede) other he denieth all the whole, becauſe the very ſame, which ſemeth a part, is no leſſe but all the whole, or els he denieth therof nothing at
all, becauſe that, whiche ſemeth a parte, is therof no part at all. And ſuche (as I ſaide) is the trewth of the faith: which althoughe it haue no partes in dede, yet I will not ſaie, but partes it ſemeth to haue, & that is onely by reaſon of the diuerſitee of tharticles, wherin it is. And not in reſpect of it ſelfe, whiche is whole (as I ſaide) in the whole feith, And yet neuer the leſſe whole alſo in euery ſingular parte therof. And therfore becauſe it is in euery ſingular article, whiche are diuerſe and many, it is thought (of ſuche as vnderſtande it not) that it ſelfe alſo is diuerſe and many likewiſe: which (as it dothe by reaſon apere) is nothing ſo. wherfore when that, which an heretike denieth in any parte of the faith, is not nothing, but with out queſtiō ſome what in dede. And when that ſame ſome what, can be no part of that, whith hath no partes, it muſte nedes folow, that the ſame, which he denieth, is no leſſe then al the whole: And that is none other but only trewth, wherof the whole feith can haue no more, then the leaſt part of it hath: And therfore in that part, which he denieth; he denieth the whole trewth of all the whole faith: wherof this muſte alſo folow, that all heretikꝭ are deceued, not only in thoſe articles, whiche they directly denie, but alſo in thoſe, whiche they ſeme and thinke them ſelues to graunte, as here after it ſhall more plainly appere.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Yet I ſhall ſaie to the contrary, more then perchance wil like you to here.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: I care not for that: And therfore ſpare not, ſaie what thou wilte.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: I tolde you before, that the trewthe of one thinge, can not be the trewthe of an other: what ſaie you to that?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
I ſaie to it this: if thou haddeſt ſaid as
much of the propre being of any thing, wherby it is made not the ſame that an other thinge is, I wold haue holden well with all. For in dede the propre beeing of one thing, can not be the propre beeing of an other. But to ſaie, that the trewth of one thing, can not be the trewth of an other, is euen as trewe, as it is to ſaie, that the name of one thing, can not be the name of an other: when moſte manifeſt and commune experience doeth declare the contrarie.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: I will not denie, but that the name of one thing, maie be the name of an other. As Iohn maie be & is the name of two men, and of many mo: yet in whom it chaunceth ſo to bee, there is Iohn and Iohn at the leaſt. But Iohn and Iohn can be no leſſe thē two, & two can be no leſſe then one & another: And betwene one & on other, there muſt nedꝭ be ſome difference: wherfore, there is a difference, betwene Iohn and Iohn. And euen ſo likewiſe there is, betwene the trewth of one thinge, and the treuth of an other. for betwene two articles, if thei be both trew, ther can be no leſſe, then trewth and truth: alſo truth and truth can be no leſſe then two: And two (as I ſaide) can be no leſſe then one and an other: & betwene one and an other, ther muſt nedꝭ be a difference. Wherfore ther is a difference betwene the trewthe of one article, and the trewthe of an other: and this is directly ageinſt all that ye haue ſaid.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
yea but yet becauſe all that I haue ſaid, is well proued and fortified by inuincible reaſon, it is meete to trie, whether all that thou haſte ſaide herein, maie be ſo proued likewiſe or not, as I wot it can not: for where thou ſaieſt, that Iohn and Iohn can be no leſſe then two: what two meaneſte thou (two men, or two names? If thou meane two men, it is nothing to the purpoſe. If thou meane two names,
whiche be they?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Iohn and Iohn.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: and is Iohn and Iohn two names?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: it is one and an other.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: That is falſe: for Iohn and Thomas, is one and an other, where as Iohn and Iohn, is but one and the ſame, which differeth muche, from one and an other. For one and an other maketh diuerſitee: but one and the ſame, can neuer paſſe vnitee. Wherfore as it is betwene Iohn, the name of one man, & Iohn the name of an other: euen ſo it is likewiſe, betwene the trewth of one article and the trewth of an other: wherin I graunt there is trewth and trewth, and yet not one and an other (whiche as I ſaide maketh diuerſitee) but one and the ſame, which paſſeth not vnitee.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: Yet ſith ye graunt that there is trewthe and trewth, if there were therin no difference nor diuerſitee, what doeth this worde (and) betwene them, whiche is a copulatiue and ioigneth two together?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Therin thou muſte conſider, that this worde (and) doth not ſo couple trewthe and trewthe together, in ſuche ſorte as thou takeſt it. Forhere, trewth in the ſeconde place, is but the only repeticion of the ſame in the firſt place: and the repeticion of a thynge, in reſpect that it is a repeticion, doeth alwaie ſomewhat differ from the thyng it ſelfe, which is repeted, as it doeth clerely appere by this, that the one maie be without the other: wherfore, this copulatiue (and) doth ioigne together truth, and the repeticion of the ſame, and not trewthe and trewthe, as two ſundrie thinges, whiche in dede is but one repeted agein.

sp.speaker: HE.
sp.p:
Syr although this be pretily excuſed, yet whē it is ſaide, ther is trewth in the reſurrection and trewth in thaſcencion, truth in the ſeconde place ther, cā be no repeticiō of the ſame in ye firſt place: becauſe there is nother relaciō, nor yet repeticiō of any of thē both, but only a demō ſtracion
and a ſhewyng wherin it is. And yet there, the copulatiue doeth ioigne them together neuer the leſſe. Wherfore thei are, and muſt nedes be of ſome difference.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Thou art yet deceiued. For there, the copulatiue hath reſpect to tharticles, ioignyng them together, in the poſeſſion of trewthe, and in the reherſall of the ſame: And not to the trewthe, whiche in them both is but one in reſpecte of it ſelfe. For where it is ſaide, there is trewthe in the reſurrection, and trewthe in thaſcencion, doubtles the very ſame ſentence maie as well be ſaide in theſe woordes: The reſurrection, and thaſcencion, haue the trewth in eache of them: wherin it doth well appere, what the copulatiue ioigneth together: And that is not trewthe and trewthe, whiche is all one: But one article and an other, whiche are no leſſe then twaine.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: Yet all this doth not ſatiſfie me.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: That is becauſe thou art perchaunce one of thoſe, that will not bee ſatiſfied.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Naie ſir I am none of theim.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Then becauſe thou doeſt wade ſo farre in the matter, tell me what is the trewthe of a thyng?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: I myght therin tell you my fantaſie, whiche perchaunce ye wolde not lyke. And therfore I had rather lerne it of you.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: I thinke thou wilt not denie, but that the trewthe of any thynge, is what ſo euer maie trewly be ſaide therof.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Then wyll I ſaie this, that of any thynge it maie trewly be ſaide, that it is.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
Thou ſaieſt well therin: And therfore the ſame at the leaſt, is the trewthe therof. For if the thynge wer not, this coulde neuer be trewe, to ſaie it is. Wherfore, name thou ſome certaine thyng, wherin this trewth
maie appere.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Ye maie name what ye will, although it were but a ſticke or a ſtone, it is enough (as I thinke) for the purpoſe.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Then a ſtone be it, if thou wilt. For of a ſtone, as of any other thynge, it muſt nedes be trewe, that it is.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: That is out of queſtion.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Therfore if this trewthe of beyng, were not in the ſtone, wilt thou ſaie, that the ſtone coulde bee?

sp.speaker: HERET.
sp.p: No not ſo.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: And is not euen that ſame trewthe, in, and of an other ſtone, as well as in, or of, this or that ſtone, yea and of euery ſtone beſide likewiſe?

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: In that I will no farder contende.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Therfore, why ſaieſt thou, that the trewth of one thynge can not be the trewthe of an other, when this is plaine, that a flint ſtone is one thynge, and a marbell ſtone is an other. And yet maieſt thou here clerely perceiue and ſee one trewth, in and of them both: and verifieth the beyng, not onely as well of the one as of the other: but alſo of all other thynges beſide, of what ſorte or kynde ſo euer thei bee.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: Naie then, if it be ſo, that one trewthe doe (as who ſaie) inhabite all maner of thynges (as you ſaie now it doth in dede) I praie you tell me, how cometh this to paſſe, that ſo great peigne, labor, and trauell, hath euer bene, & daily is taken, in counſailes, courtꝭ, ſcholes, vniuerſities, and diuers other waies, for the ſerche and triall of the trewth? when (if your ſaiyng be trewe) there is no ſorte of men, hauing the vſe of reaſon, but hath it in ſome kynde of thynges all redy. And therfore what wold thei haue more, or what nede any farder labour for it?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
although thei haue it alredie in many thynges. Yet they haue it not therfore in all thynges. Amonge the whiche, it is ſone had in ſome of theim, by experience: And in ſome of theim, not without ſome labour,
but in ſome of them, not without a longe and ſtudious diligence, and that ſpecially in diuers caſes of lernyng: by reaſon wherof, ther is oft times had in ſchooles many great & graue diſputacions: and for the fortifiyng of the dewe order of reaſon therin (by the whiche the trewthe ſo trauailed for, muſt nedes be gotten, or els it wyll not be had) there are brought in many ſundrie and ſtronge principles and rules, whiche beare in them ſelfes, ſuche an ineuitable and manifeſt trewthe, as no man with reaſon, can or will denie.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p:
Sir I praie you ſtaie there a while. For this will I ſaie, that if there be amonge all thoſe principles and rules, whiche ye ſpeake of, any diuerſitee of trewth, that is to ſaie, any other trewth in any one of them, then there is in any of the other, or in all to gether: then haue I my purpoſe. Of the other ſide, if ther be no diuerſitee of trewth among them, but that the ſame trewth, whiche is in any one of them, is alſo in eache of the other and in all to gether, then are thei all, (one except at the moſt) but euen vaine and very ſuperfluous: when that ſame one, hath none other, but the very ſame and as muche trewthe in it, as hath all the reſte beſide. And therfore that one were enough and ſufficient of it ſelfe without nede of any moe, but euen of that alone: and yet not of that nother, if it be well weighted. For when that ſerueth but only to the findyng & obteinyng of the trewth, which is (as you ſay, had in the ſame & ſome other thyngꝭ all redy, what is it els but as though I might goe ſeke that thyng in the felde, whiche I am ſure of before in my chambre? And therfore if ther be but one truth, in all and euery thynge that is: & euery man hath the ſame all redie in one thynge or other: vaine & ſuperfluous are all counſels, courtꝭ, ſcoles, diſputacions, inquiſiciōs, ſerches & ſuch
other induſtrious indeuers, made for thobteining therof.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Depely reaſoned and well fro the purpoſe: for I haue tolde the already, that although they haue it in ſome thinges, yet thei haue it not in all thinges.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: What is that to the purpoſe? for when thei haue it all redie, what nede they ſeeke (as I ſaied) any farder for it?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
Now I perceiue it plaine, that litle doeſt thou conſider, how diuerſly trewth (which is not diuerſe) in diuerſe thinges behaueth it ſelfe: for returne thy conſideracion but euen to ſtones ageine, and of the which, thou ſhalt perceiue in ſome, the trewth to ſhow it ſelfe ſo manifeſtly, that no man douteth of what ſorte or kinde they be. And in ſome, it kepeth it ſelfe ſo priuely, that few mē knoweth the verie trewe ſtone from a counterfeit, except he be a good lapidarie: Alſo in ſome other kynde of thinges, it behaueth it ſelfe, yet ſo muche more darkely: that it chaunceth to the cource but of fewe men therin to come to it, and yet that not without muche difficultee. And farder, it lieth in diuerſe and many caſes ſo ſecretly, that all the wittes of men, can not atteine to the knowlage therof, excepte it be coniecturally. And yet is it in ſome of them, for vs, and of vs to be had, moſt expedient and neceſſary: And therfore amonge them, where the capacitee of mannes witte dooeth faile, it pleaſeth the goodnes of god, that trewe faith, with good zele, ſhall yet catche holde, and therin much preuaile: And therfore, when this is moſt plaine, that mā hath much more gretter nede of trewth, in ſome thinges then in ſome: & ageine, when thoſe thingꝭ wherin he hath moſt nede therof, are of that ſorte, whiche (as who ſaie) kepeth it moſte ſecretly, and
fardeſt from his knowlage and vnderſtandinge, howe ſhulde he therin come by it, but by ſuche wais & meanes, as are moſte mete and conuenient for it? and what wais and meanes ar thoſe, if wit & trewth be not two of them? for who, without ſufficient capacitee of wit, can therin preuaile or atteine vnto it? Of the other ſide, who, without trewth, is able to ſeeke, and come by trewth? except thou wilte ſaie, it may be ſought and gotten by falſhed, which is not poſſible: Therfore no man without trewth, is able to ſeeke and come by trewth,Iohn. 14. ſpecially when theſe be the wordes of trewth, I am the way, trewth, and life.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: The way, trewth, and life, what are thoſe three, to this purpoſe?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
Uery much, if thou marke this well, that the ſpeaker therof, muſte nedes bee one of thoſe three at the leaſte: for when the ſpeaker doth ſay (I am) and declareth what, that is to ſay, the waie, trewth, and life, it can not be auoided, but of the three, trewth at the leaſt (whiche is one of them) muſte nedes be the ſpeaker of it, becauſe it is not poſſible, for this to be trewly ſaide of any ſpeaker (I am the trewth) but euen onely of trewth it ſelfe: And therfore, becauſe trewthe ſaieth alſo here of it ſelfe, that it is the way: it muſte nedes folowe, that the wey, is the trewth to: for the trewth, could not trewly ſaie, that it ſelfe were the way, excepte the waie were the trewth: And yet more ouer, becauſe it ſaith farder of it ſelfe, that it is the life, the life alſo muſte nedes be the trewth likewiſe, although it beareth here (as the waie doth) an other name: for the trewthe could not trewly ſaie, that it ſelfe were the life, except the life were the trewth. And for ſo much as there is no way,
that tendeth not to an ende, clere it is therfore, that this way, muſt nedes haue an ende: wherfore, as this way, which is the way of truth, far paſſeth al maner of waies, euen ſo it muſt nedes haue an ende, farre paſſinge all maner of endes: And becauſe there is no ende comparable to perfitte life without ende. Therfore that ſame life, muſt nedꝭ be the ende of this way, and yet not ſo, as though the ſame were not alſo the truth it ſelfe. for when it is playne, that farder then trewth, trewth can not go. Trewth muſt nedes be the ende of trewth alſo, which (as I ſaid) is perfit life without ende. wherfore, this I may well conclude and ſay, that trewth is the way wherin, and trewth is the beginnyng from whence, and treuth is the ende wherunto, for the which cauſe (as I ſuppoſe) the propre name of trewthe is there placed in the middes betwene the other two, as who ſaith indifferente or the ſame, to and with them bothe. wherfore by this thou maiſt perceue and ſee, that theſe three, ar much to the purpoſe, which is to ſhow, that the treuth of one thing, is the the very waie, to come by the trewth of an other.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: ye but what nede a man to ſeke it in one thinge, when he hath it all redie in an other?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Becauſe he hath (as I ſaied, and as it is plaine) not only much more nede of it in one thing, then he hath in an other, but alſo becauſe, for the ſtraieng, and diuerſe behauiour therof, it is therin, more harde to come by, then it is in an other.

sp.speaker: HE.
sp.p: Then ſir all this notwithſtandinge, if the waie, trewth,Ioan. 14. & life, which are three, be all but euen one trewth, why is it put ſo diuerſly, as though it were otherwiſe?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: That queſtion will make but a digreſſion nothing to my purpoſe.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p:
yet it ſhall be
ſomwhat to my purpoſe for all that, if ye anſwere it.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Then for aunſwere take this, thou ſhalt vnderſtand, that trewth, in reſpect of the propre eſſenciall and verie being of it ſelfe, can neither receue either more or leſſe, that is to ſaie, it can neither increaſe, nor decreaſe, augment, or diminiſhe: But yet in reſpect of the beeing therof in mannes vnderſtanding, it maie dooe bothe, as of the one ſide we maie well and eaſily perceue it, by the fruictes and profite of that induſtrie and diligent labour, whiche many beſtoweth about the ſame. For to what intente are children ſette to ſchole? or to what purpoſe doeth all ſtudentes labour and traueil in any ſcience? More ouer, wherfore are all inquiſitions and ſerches made? but onely to come by the more trewth?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: For to come by the more knowlage ye maie ſaie.

sp.speaker: CAT.
sp.p:
Why, what is knowlage without trewth? ſpecially when this is moſte trewe, that nothinge can be knowne, but onely by the trewth therof. for as the power of ſight with out light, nothinge can dooe, And therfore, no light, no ſight: Euen ſo the power of knowlage without trewthe likewiſe can nothing do nother. And therfore no trewth, no knowlage, except thou wilt cal this knowlage, to take one thinge for an other, or any thing to be otherwiſe then it is, which is in dede but very blinde ignorance, and nothing els: wherfore, who ſo euer ſeketh after the knowlage of any thinge, ſeketh in dede nothinge els, but the trewthe therof, whiche obteined, the thinge is knowne, and otherwiſe not. Ageine, who ſo euer ſeeketh the trewthe of any thinge, hath all readie the trewthe, of ſome other thinges, or els it were not poſſible for him to go aboute it, as it maie well appere, by the cauſe why, that yong infantes are not compelled to ſchole, or
other feates of knowlage, vnto the tyme, their potencial capacite of trewthe, become to ſome actuall poſſeſſion therof. Therfore becauſe the deligent induſtrie and labour of all ſtudentes, of the one ſide, and alſo thintencion of all inquiſicions and ſerches, of the other ſide, dothe plainly proue and declare, that ſome men alwaie dooe ſeke after trewth, and that not in vaine, as it doth appere, by that thei do therin more and more increaſe, and daylie obteine. And agein, becauſe they nother wolde, nor coulde ſo dooe, if they had not alredie, the trewth of many thinges before, to ſette them a worke therin: it muſt nedes folowe, that trewth in mans vnderſtandinge doth, and may dayly grow and increaſe more and more.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: And what of all this.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
I ſhall tell the what, becauſe this is plaine, that increaſe can neuer bee, but from the leſſe to the more. And agein, for ſo much, as from the leſſe to the more, can be no paſſage, but by a right conuenient meane and waie betwene them. Therfore is man herin ſo taught the waie, that there can be no miſtruſt or any dout therof, when trewth, which can not lie, doeth ſaie of it ſelfe, I am the waie. And yet becauſe, ther is lightly no waie, but maie other by the ignorance, or ſome other imperfection of the ſtraieng trauelar therin, be ſoone miſſed and loſte, with out a ſuer guide. Therfore is he taught alſo, to take none other, but euen the ſame to be his guide, which hath trewly told him the waie, becauſe there is none, nor none can be to a man, ſo good and ſure a guide in his iourneie, as the trew teacher therof, whiche is alſo the verie trewthe, as it ſelfe doeth ſaie, when it ſaieth, I am the way. And yet farder more, for ſo much as ther groweth in a iourneie of long and tedious labour, ſuch a werineſſe, as might chaunce to cauſe
the trauelar to feint, ſlake, and ceaſſe to continue therin, and ſo to geue ouer his purpoſe, excepte ther be ſome ſuch notable thynge, to be loked for in the ende, as maie well and iuſtly, ſo kindle his deſyre therof, that for the whiche he ſetteth all his labour at nothynge: the trauelar therfore in the iourney and labour of this waie, is moſt trewly inſtructed, and throughly aſſured of ſuche a benefite and commoditee to folowe therof, as is of all thynges moſte excellent and in comparable: for what is comparable to perfecte life without ende, whiche aboue all thynges is moſt deſiderable? And therfore that is the veraie ende, where vnto this waie doothe euer more leade and directely tende: wherof the trauellar (if he holde on his iourneie and goe thorowe with all) is moſte aſſured by the promeſſe of no leſſe than the very mouth of trewth it ſelfe, whiche doothe ſaie: I am the life. And therfore by this it maie well appere, that in what ſo euer is rightly doone and well brought to paſſe, Trewthe is the beginnyng, The ende, and alſo the weie betwene them: that is to ſaie, the waie wherin the purpoſe is folowed: The trewth, wherby it is firſt ſet a worke. And the ende, wherunto it is finally brought. And yet all three, no more, no leſſe, nor none other, but euen one trewthe: without the whiche, what is the waie? what is the beginnyng? or what is the ende of any thynge but all vaine and nothing worthe? And therfore to ſhewe, that trewthe is the only perfection of all and eache of them three, it dothe here ſet furthe and daclare it ſelfe accordyngly with this triplicite of wordes,Iohn. 14. ſayng I am the weie, trewth, and life: as muche to ſeie, as without me, There is no weie ſtreight, no beginnyng good: nor no ende profitable. Wherfore nowe thou haſt herde for anſwere to thy queſtion
(as I ſuppoſe) a good cauſe why, that trewth, which is but one, is here ſo diuerſely put, as though it were other wiſe: Muche more herof there might be ſeide, but this is enough for the purpoſe.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Sir I am glad I haue herde yow ſaie ſo muche: for ye concluded before, that what ſo euer is more or leſſe then trewthe, can be no trewthe at all. And yet here nowe ye ſaie, it maie be more and more: as your ſaiynges therof dooeth plainly declare.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Saied I, more and more?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Yea more and more.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Wherof?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Of trewthe.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: That is well ſaied: And putteſt thou no difference betwene more or leſſe of trewthe, And more or leſſe then trewthe?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: What difference ſhulde I put therin?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
Aſke thine owne eie, wherby thou maieſt lerne it. For by more of light, thou maieſt ſee the better. But by more then light, thou canſt ſee nothynge at all. For what is more then light, but vtterly no light? and what is no light, but the contrarie, whiche is veraie darkeneſſe? And agayne, what is leſſe then light, but alſo euen the ſame likewiſe? therfore more or leſſe of light, and more or leſſe then light, are two thyngꝭ. For by more then light, light is excluded: but by more of lighte, lighte is but increaſed. And euen ſo likewiſe of trewthe. For by more then trewthe, trewthe is cleane excluded: but by more of trewth, trewth, (where it maie) is but increaſed. For he that telleth the but parte of a trewe tale, dothe tell the leſſe of the trewthe, then doothe he, that trewly telleth the, the whole tale: And he that telleth the, the whole tale, doth tell the more of the trewthe,
then doth he, that telleth the, but parte of it: and yet both trewe. But if thou perceiue, that he dothe tell the more then the trewthe of the whole: or leſſe then the trewthe of any parte: woldeſt thou not take hym for a lier or a miſreporter of the matter? Yea and that iuſtely: Becauſe he is no leſſe in dede.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Then by this, it dothe yet appere, that one article of the feithe maie haue more or leſſe of trewthe, then an other hath.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: No not ſo nother, for the trewthe is not ſeied (as I tolde the before) to be other more or leſſe, for any thynge that is in it ſelfe, but onely in reſpecte of and for the numbre of thynges wherin it is, and wherof it is had: Becauſe that ſame numbre of thynges, wherin it is, and wherof it is had, is in owre knowlage, ſomtime more, and ſomtime leſſe. And for that cauſe it is ſeide to bee more or leſſe: and for nothynge els. For when it is ſeide that a man knoweth more of the trewthe to daie, then be did yeſterdaie, it is not properly to be vnderſtande and taken, that he knoweth more trewthe, but the truthe of more matter, or of mo thynges to daie then he knewe yeſterdaie, and not more of the trewth it ſelfe, whiche can not be, other more or leſſe. And beſide this, although more or leſſe of trewth maie be ſeide in reſpecte of the beyng therof in mannes knowlage, by reaſon of the comyng and goyng of thingꝭ to and fro, as thexperience therof doth declare: yet it can not be ſo ſeide in any other kynde of thynges, which haue no ſuche actiuite or capacite of vnderſtandynge or diſcernynge one thynge from an other, as the priuilege of mannes nature hath. And therfore all this, maketh nothynge for thy purpoſe.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: it is no maruell as ye do handell it.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
So longe as I handill it acording to truth, there is no faute to be founde therin. And therfore although thou haſt driuen it of, very lōge: yet it maie this very well appere, that it is nother vaine nor ſuperfluous, that learned men take with theim in their diſputacions many rules and principles of trewthe, to conducte eyde and kepe the dewe order of reaſon, from all deuiacion and errour, vntill it come as it were to the porte and finall concluſion of that, whiche therby is intended: for as a man hauynge a farre longe, and a ſtrange iourney to trauaile, had nede ſome tyme of ſondrie guides, becauſe it maie chaunce one, whiche can conducte hym twentie myles, can not yet guide hym three ſcore, by reaſon his knowlage of that waie extendeth not ſo farre, and therfore muſt nedes be had an other, and perchaunce diuerſe moe, after as the caſe requireth: euen ſo mans witte and reaſon, hauynge vrgente occaſion, to ſerche and ſeeke trewthe, in ſuche neceſſary thynges, as kepeth it veraie ſecret, and farre from his knowlage: hath much nede of certain and ſondrie ſuche guides, as are for that purpoſe moſte conuenient and neceſſarie, that is to wit, diffinicions, diſtinctions, reſpectes, and diuerſe other lyke rules of in fallible trewthe, to leade and conueie it directely from one thynge to an other, vntill it come there, where it obteineth, the ſame it deſyreth. And though there bee therin, none other ſought nor yet founde, but euen the veraie ſame trewthe, whiche was had before in many thynges: yet is it not laboured in vayne, nor without neede nother, becauſe it was hidde, and not hadde before in that one thynge, wherein it was perchaunce, more expediente to bee had, then in diuerſe and many
other thinges beſide: Wherfore, when no man can come to trewthe, but by the wey and meane of trewth (for trewth will in no wiſe be obteyned or towched, but by the way and meane of it ſelfe) why doeſt thou thinke it ſo ſtraunge a matter, that men labour therin, ſo ſore for the ſame which they haue alredy? that is to ſaie, for the ſame trewth in one thinge, whiche they haue alredy in an other, when the trewth of one thing, is the way and meane, to come (as I ſayde) by the trewth of an other. for otherwiſe it will not be had. Wherfore now I ſuppoſe, thou art in this cace, ſufficiently anſwered.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Sir let that waie as it maie here after, for I dout not but ye will yet graunte me this, that blacke and white, as in ynke and paper are two diſtincte and contrarie colours.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Agreed.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Then if there be no more, no leſſe, nor none other, but euen the very ſame trewth in the blacke, that is in the white, and the ſame in the white, that is in the blacke, why ſhulde it not be as trewe to ſaie, the blacke is white, and the white blacke, as it is to ſay, the blacke is blacke, and the white is white, if there be (as you ſay) but one indifferente trewth of them bothe?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
There is no more in dede, but yet becauſe the ſelfe ſame one trewth whiche doth verifie the blacke to be blacke, and the white to be white, is alſo as well in the difference of both thoſe colours, and ſo doth verifie the ſame likewiſe, as it is in eache and both the colours them ſelues, it doeth therfore vtterle forbid it ſo to be ſaide, as thou ſpeakeſt it. becauſe if thou ſay the blacke is white, or the white blacke. The trewth of the difference betweue them, is clerely ageinſt
the, which trewthe is al one, in al three, as it is and muſt nedes be in all other thinges likewiſe beſide.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Then will I leue all theſe kindes of thingꝭ, and go to the very ſcripture, which in this cace, is directly ageinſt you.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: How ſo?

sp.speaker: HERE:
sp.p: haue you not redde in the pſalter,Pſal. 〈◊〉 . wher this is written, Quoniam diminute ſunt veritates á filiis hominum? that is to ſaie, trewthes, ar miniſhed from the children of men, or trewthes are falen awey from the children of men. Here ye ſe, it ſpeaketh not of trewth ſingularly, but of trewthes in the pluraln umber, wherin is conteined many, which can not be without diuerſitee, & this is therfore clene ageinſt your ſaieng.

sp.speaker: CA.
sp.p: To this I will firſt anſwere the, with the wordꝭ of Saint Auſten, and afterward as I can beſide. For ſaint Auſten vpon the ſame text, doth ſay this, trewth is one, with the which, holy ſoules are illuſtrate, but becauſe there be (he ſaith) many ſoules, in thē ther may be ſaid many truthes, as in glaſſes appereth many images of one face. Here thou maiſt well perceue, by ſaint auſten, that although ther may be ſaid many truthes, and that by reaſon, of the diuerſite of thingꝭ wherin it is, yet ther is but one trewth for all that. For doeſt thou not knowe, that as one thinge maie haue diuerſe and ſondry names, ſo maie diuerſe and ſondry thinges haue one name?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: As how?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
Breade, drinke, fire, water, &c. are eache but one thing, and yet hath eyther of them, almoſt ſo manny ſondry names, as ther be ſondry languages, wherin thei are vſed to be ſpoken of neuertheleſſe the
diuerſitee of the names, doth not chaunge the vnitee or ſimplicitee of the thing, nor the vnitee or ſimplicitee of the thing, the diuerſitee of the names. And againe of the other ſide, thou maiſt eaſly finde ſome wher (as in ſome towne or pariſhe) twentie men of one name, yet the vnitee of the name, doeth not chaunge the diuerſitee of the perſons, nor the diuerſitee of the perſons, the vnitee the name. And euen ſo is it likewiſe (as I tolde the before) betwene the vnitee or ſimplicite of trewth, and the diuerſite of thinges wherin it is. For as the ſimplicite of trewth, doth not alter or change, the diuerſite of thinges, wherin it is. So the diuerſite of thingꝭ, doth not alter or chaunge, the ſimpliſite of the truth which is in them. Therfore truth in how many thingꝭ ſo euer it be, is yet (as ſaint Auſten ſaith) but one, al though of the commune ſort (for the cauſes afore ſaid) it be otherwiſe taken.

sp.speaker: HE.
sp.p: yea but yet, that commune ſort, doth ſo take it, as the ſcripture ſpeaketh it.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Nay, thou maiſt ſay this, that the ſcripture ſpeaketh it, euen as they do take it. for that the ſcripture doth ſo ſpeake it, is not the cauſe why, they ſo take it, but that they ſo take it, is the cauſe why the ſcripture doth ſo ſpeake it. for to whom (ſaieſt thou) dothe the ſcripture ſpeake it?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: To whom but to men?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Therfore euen after the commune maner, and capacite of menne it ſpeaketh it, And none other wiſe. wherin it doth not there teache any pluralitee, nor yet ſingularite, for it dothe but ſhowe after the maner of mens ſpeaking, what ſtate the children of men are in. And proueth nothinge els. wherfore this text, maketh nothing for thy purpoſe.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Sir will ye geue me leue to talke my minde a while?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Spare not.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p:
Then, if there be (as you ſay) no more, no leſſe, nor none other, but euen the very ſame one ſingle and ſimple trewth, not onely in all and euery ſingular article of the faith, but alſo in all and euery other thing and thinges, what ſo euer they bee beſide, this muſte iuſtly folowe, that who ſo euer denieth the trewth of any one thing, whether it be of the fayth, or not of the faith, denieth therin no leſſe then the trewth of all and euery thing that is. For when you wil haue it nedes followe, that he whiche denieth the trewth of any one article of the fayth, denieth therin the trewth of all the whole, becauſe there is (ye ſaie) no more, no leſſe, nor none other trewth in all the whole, then there is in eache and euery parte thereof. It muſte nedes folow likewiſe, that he whiche denieth the trewth of any other maner of thinge, denyeth therin the trewthe, bothe of all the fayth, and alſo of all other thinges what ſo euer they be beſide. Wherfore ſithe there is no man an heretike, but be cauſe he denieth the trewth of ſome part of the faith. And ageyne becauſe the very ſame trewthe whiche he denieth (if it be as you ſay) is in all and euery other thing beſide: it muſte alſo neds folowe, that who ſo euer denyeth the trewthe of any other thing, is alſo an heretike euen lykewiſe, as well as he, becauſe he denyeth no more, no leſſe, nor none other, but euen the verie ſame trewth, whiche the heretike dooeth denie. And yet farder, becauſe there is all moſte no man, but ſome tyme he denieth the trewthe of one thynge or an other. Wherin, becauſe they dooe all denie (by your ſayenge) none other but euen
alſo the ſame trewth, which an heretike doth denie, howe can this be auoided, but that all other men bee heretikes lykewiſe, euen as well as he?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: And doeſt thou beleue that to be trewe?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Nay ſyr, nor no man els I thinke.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Howe then?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Marie this, by the manifeſte falſitee of this concluſion, I doe perceiue the falſitee of the poſicion, wherof it foloweth.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Whiche is that?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Euen this that ye ſey, trewthe is no more, no leſſe, nor none other, in euery ſingular thynge by it ſelfe, then it is in theim all, euen hole to gether: whiche (as ye maie nowe ſee) can not be trewe:

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Arte thou at that poynte ageyn nowe?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: who can be otherwiſe, when it dooeth here ſo plainly appere?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Howe ſo euer thou makeſt it appere to thy ſelfe, yet it appereth not ſo, to any man els, that foloweth reaſon: for did not I tell the before, that trewth, whiche is but one, and not diuerſe, doothe yet diuerſely behahaue it ſelfe in diuerſe thynges? As I declared vnto the, ſo farre as the caſe did then require?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: What of that?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
I ſhall tell the what: becauſe I ſee the herein, ſo curious and inſaciable, that thou leueſt nothynge vnſought (ſo farre as thy wit will ſerue the) which maie ſeme to make for thy purpos, thou ſhalte yet vnderſtande this muche farder, that all maner of thynges (Wherin the trewthe is (as aforeſaide) maie be deuided, in to theſe three ſundrie ſortes, that is to wit, one contingent and caſuall: an other more certayne and naturall: And the thirde diuine and ſpirituall. And therfore in theſe three ſortes, the trewthe behaueth it ſelfe ſo diuerſely, that in thynges contingent and caſuall, it maie
be denied, without any danger or perill at all: as if thou and I ſhulde nowe contende, whether the turke be at Conſtantinople or no: if thou ſey ye, and I naie, or I ye, and thou naie, the one of vs bothe, denieth the trewthe playne. Alſo if thou ſeie the price of graine will not fall, but riſe before the yere come aboute: And I ſeie of the other ſide, that it will not riſe but fall: if it doe either the one or the other, the one of vs bothe denieth the trewthe lykewiſe: And ſo in all other thynges of that ſorte, what ſo euer thei be: yet what parell, hurte or daungier canſt thou fynde herin? when trewthe in this kynde of thyngꝭ, behaueth it ſelfe to all men (for diuers cauſes) ſo indifferently, that thei maie therin graunte or denie, accordyng to their opinions, and yet not offende therin. Ageine, in thynges whiche are more certeine & naturall, the trewth of as many as are vnknowne, leueth it ſelfe to the ſame libertee of iudgement, as it dothe in thynges contingent and caſuall: but of the reſte, whiche be manifeſte and well knowne, the trewthe can not be denied, of ſuche as dothe knowe them: as by exaumple, who can denie the fyre to be hote? no man I thinke, excepte he were out of his wit.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Yes ſyr, for a man maie denie the fyre to be hote, if he will, although he knowe the trewthe of it neuer ſo well.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: If he wolde ſo doe: what faute were that ſeieſt thou?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Suche and the ſame faute, as is the deniall of trewthe?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: yea in that thynge thou maiſte ſaie, and in ſuche other lyke: but not as it is in euery thynge beſyde. For the deniall of trewthe in ſome thynges, is (as I doubte not, but thou wilt confeſſe) no leſſe then a damnable faute.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: That is trewe.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: And dooeſt thou thinke it a damnable faute, to denie the fyre to be hote?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: No not ſo.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Yet thou thinkeſt it a more faute, then to denie the trewthe of what price, corne ſhall be the nexte yere.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: I muſte nedes thinke ſo.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: And whie?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Becauſe this deniall is of a thyng certaine, manifeſt, and directely ageyn the perfite knowlage of the deniar: where as the other is but of a thynge incertaine, contingent, caſuall, and to the deniar but coniecturall: wherfore it can not be ſuche a faute, to denie that I knowe but coniecturally, as it is to denie that I knowe moſte perfectely, as I knowe the fire to be hotte.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Then, to denie the fyre to be hotte, is worthy more blame, then the other is.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: It muſt nedes.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: And yet thou ſeiſt it is not damnable.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Therfore ſith it maie this apere, that trewthe bindeth not lyke nor ſo, in all thynges, but that (as thou doeſt graunt thy ſelfe) the deniall therof, in ſome thynge is damnable, and in ſome thynges not. And clere it is, that the damnable daunger and dammage therof, conſiſteth not in thynges contigent and caſuall: nor yet in thynges more certain and natural, but only in thinges concernyng our feithe, whiche are diuine and ſpirituall, how clerely maketh it ageinſt this that thou ſeieſt, who ſo euer denieth the trewthe of any maner of thynge, is as well an heretike as he is, whiche denieth the trewthe of any article of the feithe, becauſe the one denieth no more, no leſſe, nor none other, but euen the ſame trewth, whiche the other dothe? This (thou maieſt perceiue) can not folowe. For it is not the deniall of trewthe onely, that maketh an heretike: but it is the deniall therof, in ſuche or ſuche a thynge, and that of our feithe onely, and not in euery or any other thynge beſide our feithe.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Syr I ſeid not as ye take it, but I ſeid this, that ſo it muſte nedes folowe of this your ſeyng, that there is no more, no leſſe, nor none other trewth in any one thyng, then there is in any other, or in the whole multitude of thynges all together.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
