I wolde graunt as muche, and the ſame my ſelfe, if trewth behaued it ſelfe in euery thynge a lyke, as thou diddeſt thinke, and take it at the firſte: but nowe becauſe thou maieſt right well perceiue, howe muche thou wer therin deceiued: the trewth therfore beyng (as I ſaide) but euen one in all thynges, dooeth yet behaue it ſelfe ſo in tharticles of the feithe, that the deniyng therof in any one of them, maketh no leſſe than an heretike in dede. And further ageyne, after an other ſorte, it behaueth it ſelfe ſo, in ſuch certaine and naturall thynges, as be apparent and ſenſible, that the deniynge therof in ſome of them, maketh a wilfull and a we • warde foole, but yet no heretike for all that: becauſe there is in it no perell of damnacion. And finally, it behaueth it ſelfe ſo, in thinges contingent and caſuall, that the deniyng therof in them, maketh little, or no faute at all: and this diuerſe behauiour of truth in diuers thynges, is not without reaſon, and good cauſe whie. For in the firſte caſe, it committeth it ſelfe, onely to the perpetuall helthe and welthe of mannes ſowle. In the ſeconde caſe, to the temporall neceſſite of this lyfe, and exerciſe of mannes witte and reaſon. And in the thirde and laſte caſe, onely to the libertee of mannes opinion: In whiche three, the deniall therof, can not be of one degre but of diuers. And therfore, of ſo farre vnlyke parell and ieoperdie, as there is difference betwene eternall dānacion, & in ſome caſe no penaltee, wherfore it is
plaine, that the deniall of trewth, is not hereticall, but wherin it behaueth it ſelfe, only to the helth and welth of mans ſoule, and that is not in thinges (as I ſayd) contingent and caſuall. Nor yet in thinges of any cource naturall, but onely in thinges theologicall, that is to ſaie, in thinges diuine and ſpirituall. Now therfore, tell me where are all thy ſore obiections be cum, which thou haſt hitherto made, ageinſt the pure inuinſible vnite and ſimpliſitee of trewth? wherin thou haſt cauſed, a much more waſt of time thou neded by a great deale. And al to excuſe colour, and hide the moſt miſerable ſtat of an heretike, which, when thou haſt all done, will yet appere, and aſke the no leue. For when the articles of the feith, are diuerſe and many, And the trewth of them all but one (as thou maiſt now perceue thy ſelfe) how can this be auoided, but he that denieth the ſame one, denieth the trewth of them all together? when they, both eache and all together, haue no more, no leſſe, nor none other, but euen the ſame one, as it is declared and proued vnto the before. For els, how commeth it thus to paſſe, that the deniall of one article, ſhuld purchaſe damnacion, rather then the graunt and confeſſion of all the reſte, ſhulde purchaſe ſaluacton? It ſemeth much more reaſon, that the graunte and confeſſion of many, ſhulde be more able to helpe and ſuccoure, then the deniall of one, ſhuld hurte and hinder, being (as they are) of like and equall power. yet becauſe in this cace, it is farre otherwiſe then ſo, tel me why doth one denied, leſe more, then all the other graunted, can get or ſaue?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: I wolde knowe that of you.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
Trewly there is none other whie, but onely becauſe the trewth of them all, is perfite and whole in the ſame one, which is denied. And therfore the reſt can not helpe, in
whom, there whole and onely trewth is ſo refuſed. and to this it maie well be applied,1 Corin. 5. whiche tholy apoſtle Saint Paule doth ſay, Modicum fermentum to tam maſſam corrumpit, that is to ſaie, a litle leuen chaungeth the taſt of the whole lumpe of dow. wherof hath riſen (as I ſuppoſe) this olde, and very trewe prouerbe, one vice deſtroieth many vertues. And why ſo few as one? but onely becauſe, the perfection and vnitee of trewth, (which is not onely, in all vertues whole together, but alſo in each and euery one vertue by it ſelfe alone) is refuſed and contemned in the committing of any one mortall vice, that chaunceth to fall in man. And therfore becauſe in vices, there is multiplicitee of errour, and contrariwiſe in vertues, very ſimplicitee of trewth, when ſo euer any one vertue is contemned, all the reſt can not helpe, becauſe in that one, ther whole perfection and indiuiſible trewth, is cleane deſpiſed. This the holy ſcripture dothe well confirme, which doth ſaie,Iaco. 2. Quicum
que totam legem ſeruauerit, offendat autem in vno factus eſt omniū reus, that is to ſay, who ſo euer doth kepe the whole lawe, and offendeth but in one parte, he is yet made giltie of all together. Now therfore content thy ſelfe with enough, and take this for an infallible trewth (as I tolde the before, and now is ſufficiently proued) that who ſo euer denieth any parte of the faith, denieth therin the trewth of all the whole. And who ſo euer denieth the trewth of all the whole feith, denieth the trewth of Chriſt. And who ſo euer denieth the trewth of Chriſt, denieth him. And who ſo euer denieth him, denieth God him ſelfe. And this (as I ſaid) doth euery heretike without faile. Wherfore now, iudge thou thy ſelfe, in what cace they leade their liues.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Sir herin I muſt nedes make with you a greate ſtaie before we paſſe any farder.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: What yet ageyn?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: yea trewly.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: why ſo?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Becauſe the Turkes and diuerſe other nations, deny Chriſt, and yet they deny not god.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Thinkeſt thou ſo?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Ye and ſo doth euery man.

sp.speaker: CAT.
sp.p: That is not trewe, for ſo do not I.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: why?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Becauſe I know the contrary, for this can not be auoyded, but who ſo euer denieth Chriſt to be the ſame that he is, denieth him vtterly. And moſte trewe it is, that he is very god, wherfore who ſo euer denieth him denieth god. And euen ſo doth the turkes.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Then how commeth it to paſſe, that they do otherwiſe thinke?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: What ſpeakeſt thou here, of a turkiſh thinking, while we be in matters of our faith whiche they refuſe?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Sir I ſpeake it not but becauſe it ſemeth very repugnant to this your ſaying, that who ſo euer denieth Chriſt denieth God, when the Turkes doeth the one, but not the other, ſo farre as I perceue.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: ye there thou ſaieſt well, ſo farre as thou perceueſt. But I and many other, perceue more.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: That more, wolde I faine here.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
Then thou muſte well marke and conſider this, that this worde Chriſt, doth not properly ſingnifie, his onely humanite, nor yet his onely diuinitee ſeuerally or perticularly. But it ſignifieth indiuidually and indiſtinctly one proper and ſingular perſon made of them both, like as this word, Iohn or Thomas, ſignifieth properly, nother the fleſh, nor yet the ſoule perticularly. But the very vnitee and ſingularitee of the perſon made of them both together, although it be ſome tyme otherwiſe vſed, or rather abuſed, by reaſon of
a certayne maner of ſpeache, which ſignifieth ſomtyme the whole by the name of a parte, and contrariwiſe, ſome tyme a parte by the name of the whole, but yet neuer ſo taken properly. And therefore as he, whiche denieth that ſame perſon, whiche is properly ſignified by this worde Iohn or Thomas, denieth not onely the fleſhe, but alſo the ſoule, nor only the ſoule, but alſo the fleſhe, and that for the very vnitee of perſon, wherin they ar knitte, made, and be come both one (bothe one I ſey) not in, or for any confuſion, mutation, or alteration of ther propre natures or ſubſtance, but in and for, the very ſingularite and pure vnite of perſon. Euen ſo he whiche denieth that ſame perſon, which is properly ſignified by this worde Chriſt, denieth not onely his very humanitee, but alſo his verie diuinitee, nor onely his very diuinitee, but alſo his very humanitee. And that for the propre vnitee of perſon, wherin they are knitte, made, and bee come both one, (bothe one I ſaie) not in, or for any confuſion, mutacion, or alteration of their propre natures, or ſubſtance, but in, and for the very propertee and vnitee of perſon. Wherfore, when the Turkes denie Chriſt, they deny both god and alſo the man. for Chriſt is none other but euen both together, and for that cauſe, the one can not be denied, with out the other.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Yes ſir, for they graunte Chriſt to be a very manne, but not very God.

sp.speaker: CAT.
sp.p:
Now I perceue, thou doſt not euen very wel, vnderſtand the matter. for it ſemeth by thy talke, that thou putteſt no difference, betwen ye ſignificatiō of this name (Ieſus) & ye ſignificatiō of this name Chriſt whē the
one (beſide the high and miſticall interpretacion therof) ſignifieth nothyng els but only the man. And the other, nothyng els, but onely that perſone, whiche was made bothe of god and man. For of the name of Ieſus, there hath ben diuers: but of the name of Chriſte, properly neuer but one acordyng to thexample therof taught & geuen vnto vs, by thauctoritee of our holy mother the catholike churche: whiche exaumple ſhe daily ſingeth and ſeithe, as the reaſonable ſoule and the fleſh is one man: ſo god & man is one Chriſte: wherfore, as he that graunteth me to be a bodie, and denieth my ſoule, or graunteth me to be a ſoule, and denieth my bodie, doth yet bothe waies denie me vtterly to be a veraie man, whiche conſiſteth onely in the compoſicion or copulacion of theim bothe to gether. Euen ſo he, that graunteth Ieſus of Nazareth to be a very man, & denieth hym to be very god, or graunteth him to be very god, and denieth him to be very man, dooeth yet bothe the waies denie hym vtterly to be very Chriſte: whiche conſiſteth onely, in the compoſicion or copulacion (if I maie ſo call it) of them bothe together. And therfore, if thou haddeſt ſaide this, that the turkes graūteth Ieſus of Nazareth to be a very man, but not very god, thou hadſt ſemed to haue ſaid ſomwhat like to the purpos: but when thou ſeiſt thei graunt Chriſte to be a very man, but not very god, thou reporteſt them to doe, that is impoſſible. For it is no more poſſible, in this woorde Chriſte, to dooe the one without the other, then it is poſſible in this woorde man, to denie the ſoule without the fieſhe, or the fleſhe without the ſoule, whiche can neuer be done. For in this woorde man, the deniall of the one, doth alwaie included, the deniall of the other. For no fleſſhe no man, no ſoule no man, and lykwiſe in
Chriſte, no god, no Chriſte, no man, no Chriſte. And therfore I ſaie, as I ſaide, that all thoſe, whiche denie Chriſte, denieth god hym ſelfe.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Yet me thinketh for all this, it dooeth not euen ſo fully folowe as ye make it for.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: I praie the tell me why.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Becauſe, although the Turkes denie god to bee in Chriſte, or in Ieſus of Nazareth, chooſe you whether. Yet for all that, it foloweth not, that thei denie god. For it is two thynges to denie god, and to denie hym to be in this, or in that. And therfore when he is not denied to be the ſame that he is, clere it is, that he is not denied in dede. For a thynge can not be denied, excepte it be denied to be the ſame that it is.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Yea but I ſey this, that they denie god to be the ſame that he is. For when thei denie hym to be ioyned in the vnitee of perſone with Ieſus of Nazareth, what do thei els, but euen denie Chriſt at the leaſt, whan they will none of that, whiche is Chriſte in dede? & when they (as they doe) vtterlie denie Chriſte, what doe they els, but clerelie denie hym to bee the veraie ſame that he is? Therfore what is the ſame that he is? wilt thou, or any trewe chriſten man anſwere and ſey any other, but very god and man? wherfore, when he is bothe the one and the other, what thynge is it, that ioigneth them both ſo to gether, but euen the veray vnitee of perſon, whiche is proprely ſignified by this worde Chriſte? And therfore when thei denie Chriſte, what doe thei els, but clerely denie both? & when thei denie both, may we not iuſtly ley to their charges, the very deniall of which we liſt? wherfore trew it is (as I ſaid before) that thei denie god for al this.

sp.speaker: HHERE.
sp.p: I will not ſaie ſo, for any thynge that I haue yet herde hitherto.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: what wilt thou ſaie then?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: I will ſey this, that they denie nether of them bothe, that is to ſaie nother god nor the man nother, but onely any ſuche vnitee of perſon, as is made of them both.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Euen as I might ſay, I nother denie thy ſowle nor yet thy bodie, but euen onely, any ſuche vnitee of perſon, as is made of them bothe. Wherin, what doe I denie, when I denie that but vtterly this, that thou art a man? For what is a man, but euen one whole complet perſon aduned and made of a bodie and a reaſonable ſowle? therfore, when I denie the vnitee therof, I denie the whole complete perſon. And when I denie the whole complet perſon, whiche thou art what is by nature in the, that I denie not? for whan I denie in the, no leſſe then the whole: is there any parte of it lefte, that is vndenied? for the deniall of the whole, dooeth euer more clerely exclude thexcepcion of any parte or partes therof: wherfore when the deniall of the whole, doth alwaie include the deniall of all the partes. Clere it is, that the deniall of all the partes, muſt nedes folowe and be agreable to the deniall of the whole, wherupon it dependeth. Therfore when the deniall of the whole, tendeth vtterly to the not beyng therof: the deniall of the partes which are included therin, muſt of neceſſitee tende to the ſame, that is to ſaie to the not beynge of them all lykewiſe: excepte thou wilt ſaie, that a man maie denie the whole tree: and denie not the barke or the bowes therof, or denie the whole apple, and denie not the coore or the kernell therof: wherfore herein thou makeſt but a mere cauilacion, nothyng to the purpoſe.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Yet I will not ſo geue it ouer: for ſuppoſe, that yeſterdaie, there died a man, whoſe bodie is yet vnburied: may not I therfore nowe, denie the vnitee of his perſon, who is clerely diſſolued and clene gone, and yet not therin denie his bodie nor his ſoule nother, which were the partes therof, & now remaine a ſonder.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Yes well enough.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Why than ſay you the contrary of the Turkes, whiche denie but onely the vnite of Chriſtes perſon, wherin ye ſaie they alſo denie both god and the man, whiche are the partes therof.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: So I ſey ſtill, and not without cauſe.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: That cauſe wolde I faine here?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
Then marke this, their deniall and thine in this caſe, doth include two contraries. For thy deniall rūneth no farder then vpon the vnite of a perſon, whiche is diſſoliued dede & gone. And therfore it muſt nedes be trewe: But their deniall runneth vpon the vnite of a perſon, which both is, & euer ſhall be. And therfore it muſte nedes be falſe. Alſo the partes of that which thou denieſt, are clene vntouched and not denied, by reaſon that thy deniall extendeth no farder, then to the not beyng of the vnite. wherof, although thei wer the partes, yet ſo they are not nowe. For they can not be the partes of that, whiche hath no beyng, and therefore in that they can not be denied. But the partes of that, whiche they denie, are denied in dede. Becauſe their deniall extendeth, nor to the not beynge, but to the very beyng of the vnitee, wherein and whereof they are nowe the partes and euer ſhall bee. And therfore thou muſte conſider, that it is two thynges to denie the beyng of that whiche is: and to denie the beynge of that whiche is not. Thou denieſt no more but the vnitee whiche is not. And they
denie the vnitee, whiche bothe is and euer ſhall be, which can not be denied (as I toulde the before) without the dedeniall of what ſo euer is conteined therin, And that is both god and man. And therfore thine example in this caſe will not ſerue, becauſe it is nothing lyke.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Yet if all this, be as ye ſaie, I maruell why the turkes do not perceue it. for I thinke they be men of as great wittꝭ as we be, and haue amonge them learnyng alſo.

sp.speaker: CAT:
sp.p: Thou ſhuldeſt nothing maruell therat, if thou dideſt wel conſider, theſe wordꝭ, (after ſome tranſlacion) of the holy prophet Iſai,Iſai. 7. Niſi credideritis, non intelligetis, that is to ſay, Except ye beleue, ye ſhall not vnderſtand. Wherfore, their infidelitee is the cauſe of their blindnes, which is ſuche and ſo great, as driueth them, to graunt the ſame, that they deny, & to deny the ſame that they graunt. And yet ſee it not nother, as the ſame holy prophet doeth ſay,Iſai. 6. they ſee and ſee not, they here and vnderſtande not.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Ye but how dooe they graunte the ſame they denie. And denie the ſame they graunte?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
I haue tolde the ſo much alredy, if thou be remembred: For when they graunte Ieſus of Nazareth to be but a very man and no more, they denie the ſame ageine, when they denie Chriſt, becauſe Chriſt is not only the ſame but alſo imcomparable more. Ageyn when they graunt god to be very god, and no leſſe, they denie the ſame agein, when they denie Chriſt, becauſe Chriſt is the very ſame, and alſo muche leſſe,Iſai. 8. as of him the prophet to god doth ſay, Minuiſti eum paulominus ab angelis, That is to ſaie: thou haſt made him ſome what leſſe then angels. And therefore when in him they denie, both the more, whiche is god, and alſo the leſſe which is man, what dooe they els, but of both ſides, denie in dede, the verie ſame, which
they wene and ſeme to graunt, that is to ſay, euen all to gether. Wherfore let this be ſufficient (as it is in dede) to repell thy great ſtay, made agein this that I ſayd before, whoſoeuer denieth Chriſt, denieth god, which ſaieng is moſt trew, as it is now ſufficiently proued. And therfore who ſo euer denieth god, although he do it not with his tong, yet at the leaſt he doth it in his hart. And ſo with out faile doth euery heretike, in whom, (as I ſayd before) theſe wordes of the prophet, the folyſhe man ſayd in his hart, there is no god, are well and iuſtly verified.Pſal. 13. Wherfore thou haſt now, by this much, a farder occaſion, wherby thou maiſt the better perceue and ſee, what maner of ſtate it is, wherin euery heretike leadeth his life.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Yet ſir when ye haue all doone, becauſe the effect of your concluſion is this, that there is no heretyke, but he denieth the trewth of all the whole faith, and therfore of Chriſt and god hym ſelfe alſo. How therfore (I pray you) maie this agree with all, (which is not vnknowne) that all heretikes doth both holde and confeſſe, diuerſe and many articles of the faith, as erneſtly, and as vehemently as any other man can, ſeyng and alſo thinking them ſelues, as verely to beleue them, as any men dooe, yea and wolde ſuffre death therin, rather then denie them.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Suffer death? nay ſofte, therin thou goeſt to farre, for thou art not able to defende that ſeying, by any authenticall writing, reaſon, or example.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Yes ſir by example, for ye can not denie your ſelfe, but many haue willingly ſuffered death, for the trewth of diuerſe poyntes of the feyth.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
Yea but what many were thoſe I pray the? any heretikes
troweſt thou?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: why not?

sp.speaker: CA.
sp.p: No trewly, for is there any deth ſo pretious and profitable, that maie come to man, as to die for the trewth of any parte of the faith?

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: I thinke not.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Therfore when it chaunſeth any mā to ſuffer deth for that cauſe, is it to be thought to cum of the man him ſelfe, or els of the great grace and gift of god?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: when all that is good, cummeth of god, that muſt nedes be aſcribed vnto him alſo.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
Thou ſayeſt wel therin,Pſal. 115. And therfore: when this is written, Preſioſa in conſpectu domini, mors ſanctorum eiꝰ, that is to ſaie, in the ſight of god precious is the death of his ſainctes. And when no deth amonge them is ſo precious, as to dy for the trewth of the faith (in ſo much, that the gifte therof, is not geuen to all thoſe, whiche holdeth the trewth of the whole faith, nor yet, but to fewe of them nother in compariſon) wilt thou thinke, that euer any heretike, which hath directly forſaken (at the leaſte) ſome parte of the faithe, other dyd or ſhall obteyne that gifte? ſithe ſo many of them goeth with out it, whiche cleueth to the whole fayth all together. Beſide this, wh eneuery heretyke, whiche forſaketh directly (as I ſaied) ſome parte of the ſaythe, doth it freely, of his owne wilfull mynde, with out any coaction or compulſion at all. will any man thinke, that he wolde ſticke at the deniall of any other parte therof, if he were conſtrayned vnto it, with no leſſe then the feare and payne of death? Specially when tholy goſpell doth ſaie Qui in modico iniquus eſt, Luc. 13. et in maiori iniquus eſt, he that is (he ſeyeth) vniuſt in litle, is alſo vniuſte in more? for he that wolde denie the, of one grote of thy duetie, with out any prouocation of nede, I thynke wolde not ſtycke, ſoone to denie the of twentie, yf he felt any neede pricke hym ther
unto. Therfore, neuer ſai or thinke that an heretik, which hath with out compultion, forſakē and directly denied, ſome parte of the fayth all redy, wold ſuffre deth, for any other parte therof, when the moſt part of thoſe (as I ſeid) which hath & holdeth the whole faith altogether, ſhall not reach or attene to that gift of moſt precious deth, which is not geuen (as I ſaid) but to few in compariſon. And yet thoſe, in whom ther is the confeſſion of the whole fayth, (thou maiſt wel know) muſt nedes be nere it, then thoſe, in whom there is the deniall of parte. extepte thou wilte make betwene them this difference, that in the one there is ſome poſſibilite thereof, and in the other none at all.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: why ſir, yet I haue harde ſay, that there haue bene diuerſe heretikes, whiche hath ſuffered death for ſome parte of the fayth.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Yea but how?

sp.speaker: HE.
sp.p: How ſay you?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: In very dede as a thefe, when he is hanged, doeth ſuffre deathe, for ſome parte of the commune welth.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: That is a proper ſimilitude.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Moſt meete for the purpoſe that I can finde.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Why ſir, a theefe is not hanged, but for that he doeth ſteale

sp.speaker: CATHO.
sp.p: Thou arte therein deceued. for if he ſteale, money, horſe, kyne, ſheepe, or ſuche other lyke, becauſe his lyfe is muche better then any of thoſe thinges, it were therfore no Iuſtice nor equitee, but rather very crudelitee to take his lyfe a way for any of them, when that puniſhmente ſo farre excedeth the value of that he ſtole. And therefore he is not hanged for any ſuche thinges.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Wherfore then?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
Becauſe he and all ſuche, are ſo iniurious and hurtfull to the commune welthe, that if they ſhulde lyue and continewe, it ſhulde by them, ſo decaie, and be trodden vnder the foote, that no manne
ſhulde be able to kepe that he hathe, and to liue one by an other, excepte it were ſuch as coulde and wolde, plaie (as they ſaie) catche that catche maie. And therfore thei be not hanged, but for the commune welthe. And yet not becauſe thei make with it, but becauſe thei make ſo ſore, and all that thei can directly ageinſt it. And euen ſo likewiſe, I will not ſeie naie, but many heretikes haue ſuffered deathe for ſome parte of the feithe. Not becauſe thei helde with it, but becauſe they went from it, and held extremely ageinſt it. And muche more miſchiefe therin wolde haue done to it, if thei had not bene therin, by ſuch worthy dethe, preuented: And therfore any other dethe of an heretike, for the trewthe of the feyth then this, thou ſhalt neuer be able to proue.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Syr herein ye haue ſaide your conceite: but how ſey you to my queſtion?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Haue ye ſo ſoone forgotten, that vpon yur concluſion, that all heretikes dooeth denie the trewth of the whole feithe, I aſked you, how might that agree with this, that all they holde and manifeſtly confeſſe ſo many articles therof as thei doe? ſeiyng and alſo thinkyng them ſelfes therin as verely to beleue them, as any men can do?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
I maruell greatly that thou wilt haue (in this caſe) any maner of reſpecte to their ſeyng or thinkyng other, ageinſte ſo manifeſte & inuincible reaſon as I haue therin ſhewed the. For in this, be thou nowe iudge thy ſelfe: doe they, other ſaie or thinke them ſelfes any more ſuer of the trewthe in any pointe, then thei ſaie and thinke thei bee ſuer in the very ſame, wherin thei doe directly erre in dede? howe erneſtly doe they
thynke, that thei be not therin deceiued? ſhall we thinke ſo to, becauſe of that? Thoſe whiche did murder and ſleie thappoſtles (as our ſauiour hym ſelfe did prophecie) thought thei did therin great ſeruice to god.Iohn. 16. But yet for all their thinkyng, was it as thei thought? or did their thinkyng excuſe their faute, becauſe thei thought it was none? Therfore why ſpeakeſt thou to me of an heretikes thinkyng? when it is not poſſible for hym to thinke that, which were of all thingꝭ moſt expediēt for him to thinke. That is to ſaie, that hym ſelfe is an heretike: what thyng might he thinke more trewly: and yet he is not able ſo to do. Therfore neuer let his ſeiyng or thinkyng, what ſo euer it be, ſtande in thy weie, betwene the and ineuitable reaſon: wherof in this caſe thou haſte harde enough.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: In dede I wolde not ſo muche paſſe vpon that, as I dooe: if it were not more for other mens thinkyng, then for theirs, whiche are no heretikes in dede. For many of them, yea and that the moſte parte, dooeth vtterly beleue and thinke, that no heretike doth denie the trewthe of the whole feithe, nor yet any more of it nother, but euen onely of thos poyntes, wherin he doth directly erre, and differ from other faithfull people.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: I pray the who be they that ſo thinke? any other but ſuche as are not able to diſcerne and vnderſtande the thynge? or any other but ſuche, as iudgeth more by coniecture, then by any dewe order of reaſon, wherof little ſkyll they can? farre a ſonder it is, to iudge thynges as they ſeme, and to iudge them, as thei bee in dede: whiche very fewe in reſpecte can doe: ſpecially when the matters be ſomwhat darke, as they be in this caſe. And therfore, what is the iudgement or opinion of ſuche, to be pondered herein?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Syr wyll ye beleue me?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: In very dede, I my ſelfe can not yet thinke, that an heretike doth denie the trewth of thoſe articles, whiche he doth ſo manifeſtly graunt and confeſſe. And more ouer vtterly beleue and thinke therin as he ſaithe.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: What not yet?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: No trewly.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Than we muſt haue a farder talke, then I thought we ſhulde nede. For nowe I wot what thou doeſt lacke herein well enough.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Thou doeſt not conſider (I perceiue) any diverſitee of denials: but as though there were no mo but euen bare one, when there is one directe, whiche is ſo comune and alſo playne, as can gender do doubte therof: And an other, indirecte or conſequent, which is more obſcure darke and ſecrete. and therfore not ſo eaſie to be perceiued. By reaſon wherof, a thynge maie ſometyme ſeme to be graunted, when it is neuer the leſſe denied: as it is nowe in this caſe. And more plainly doth apere, in that I ſaid vnto the before of the Turkes: who (as thou ſaieſt) doth graunt god, but how? none otherwiſe but directly, deniyng the ſame ageyn conſequently: as thei do, when thei denie Chriſt, whiche maketh their graunt nothyng worth. For a directe graūt, can neuer ſtande with a conſequent denial, which plucketh awai the trewth and perfection, of what ſo euer is graunted before.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: I thought all this while, that there was ſome ſubtiltee in this deniall, whiche ye haue ſo longe ſpoken of, or els it were not poſſible, for that ye haue ſaid to be trew.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
If thou call yt, which is very conſequēt, but a ſubtilte, thou ſhalt yet finde it a ſubtiltee of ſuch a ſorte, as wherin, all heretikes deceiue not onely them ſelfes, but alſo as many
as folow them.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: That deceite maketh but a ſmall faute, ſo longe as their deniall renneth not agayne the thynge directely.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: So thou woldeſt haue it taken: but thou ſhalte finde it farre otherwiſe for all that: wherfore, although it will make ſome digreſſion before we come to the very ſolucion of thy queſtion, yet to ſee the trewthe hereof, wilt thou call that but a ſmall faute, whiche the holy prophet dooeth note in hym, that ſeith in his herte, there is no god?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: No mary ſyr,Pſal 13. for I thynke there can be no greatter faute then that, becauſe he that ſo dooeth denieth hym directly, and not conſequentely.

sp.speaker: CATHOLI.
sp.p: howe knoweſt thou that?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Uery well. for he that ſeithe in his herte there is no god, can neuer denie a thynge more directly, then he denieth that.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: If thou ſay ſo, tell me howe doth he, ſaie that in his herte?

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: He ſaith it, with the worde of his thought, which is conceued within, although it come not out with the voice.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: What is that worde of his thought.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: What ſo euer he thinketh to be ſo or not ſo.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: How many ſhall we finde, that doth with that woorde, euen ſey in the herte, there is no god?

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: Firſt how many ſo euer there be, that ſo ſeith in the herte, I thinke there be none of thē, that dare & will ſo ſaie with his mowth, or yet ſo writ with his pen. And therfore whē the worde of thought alone, is not open, but only to him, in whō it is: how ſhuld we finde any ſuch, although there were many, as I thinke there be not?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Dooeſt thou not thinke there be many of them.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: No trewly.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Why ſo.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Becauſe the prophet ſpeaketh it, but of one perſon ſingularly. For he doth not ſey, (the foliſhe men) but the foliſhe man ſaide in his herte, there is no god.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
Thou maieſt
not take it ſo, for the prophet perceuing a multitude wrapped in this horrible and abhominable blindneſſe, doth here touch and open the venemous curſidnes of all the whole ſort, in the perſon of one of them, as it may well appere by his owne wordꝭ immediately folowing, whiche are theſe. Corrupti ſunt et abhominabiles facti ſunt in ſtudiis ſuis. Pſal 13. They are (he ſaith) corrupted, and become abhominable in ther fancis. This he ſaieth (as thou hiereſt) not of one, but of many, That is to wit, of the whole ſort, whoſe moſt peſtilent wickednes, he towcheth before, (as I ſayd) in the perſon of one of them. Wherfore thou maiſt not take it, that he meaneth it of one perſon alone, or of few mo, but in dede of very many. And now therfore to the purpoſe ageine, whether this foliſh fellow, which denieth god in his hart, denieth him directly or no.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: There is no doubt of that, as I ſhowed you before.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Ye but yet thou muſte make me a better proffe therof then ſo.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Then my proffe ſhalbe this, when he ſaieth in his hert, there is no god, and the ſame ſayeng in his hert, is none other, but in his hert ſo to thinke, And becauſe no man can thinke any thinge in his hert to be ſo, or not ſo, but euen directly, it muſte nedes followe, that this foliſh felowe in his hert denieth god directly.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: That foloweth not, for where thou ſayeſt, that no man can thinke in his herte, any thing to be ſo, or not ſo, but euen directly, that I deny. For it is not trewe, except thou adde vnto it this condicion, if he be ware of it.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Why, is it poſſible for any man to thinke, that he him ſelfe is not ware of?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
why not, as well as to ſpeake, that he hym ſelfe is not ware of? for haſt thou not ſome tyme harde this report of a man, that he ſpake he wiſt nere what? and
yet neither madde, dronke, nor an Ideot nother, And why therfore, maie not a man thinke, he wot nere what as wel as ſo to ſpeake? when ſo ſpeaking can not procede but of ſo thinking?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: yea but yet, when a man doeth ſo ſpeake, it is not ſaide he ſpeaketh he wot nere what, becauſe he is not ware what he ſayth, but becauſe he is not ware what of neceſſitee foloweth of his ſeying. For of his ſaying it ſelfe, he is ware what it is well enough, or els he coulde not repete the ſame againe, which ye knowe he can do, although he be not ware what muſt folowe therof: for that is it, for the whiche it is ſaide, he ſpeaketh he wotteth nere what, and for nothinge els.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Let it ſo be. And yet, what ſo euer doth ſo folowe, that ſame both is, and muſt nedes be, conteyned in his ſaying, or els it coulde by no meanes folow therof.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: That I graunt.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Then take euen the ſame of his thinking, becauſe the reaſon and trewth therof is all one, for as he is ware of his ſaying directly, and yet is ignorant and vnware therof conſequently, That is to wit, as he woteth what he ſayth, and woteth not what dothe folow therof, which is conteyned therin, Euen ſo it is of his thinking likewiſe. for both ſaying and thinkinge haue in them commonly, a duble vnderſtanding, one direct, and on other conſequent. And therfore when the name or reporte of ſaying or thinking, procedeth and is taken very ofte, as well of that vnderſtanding which is but conſequent, as of that whiche is direct, what haſt thou more to proue, that this foliſhe fellowe which ſaieth in his hart ther is no god, denieth him in his hart directly, rather then conſequently? for all this that thou haſte hitherto ſeyde will not ſerue.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: I haue this of the prophet to proue it by, that he ſeyth in his hart, ther is no god.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: ye but yet, when this ſame ſaying in his hart, is (as afore ſayd) the very thynking in his mynd, and the ſame thinking hauinge in it as it hathe, not onley a directe ſence, but alſo a conſequente, whether dothe the prophette meane it of the directe ſence, or els of the ſence conſequete? for therin dothe lie all the doubt: becauſe the ſaying of the prophette behaueth it ſelfe indifferentlie vnto them both.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Syr the prophet muſte nedes meane it of the direct ſence of his thinkynge onely, as it may well appere by theſe wordes, which he ſpeaketh alſo of hym, ſo playnly in an other place, ſeying, Non eſt deus inconſpectu eius, Pſal. 9. There is (he ſayth no god in his ſight. And becauſe the prophet doth here not meane the ſight of the outward eye of the bodie, but the ſight of the inwarde eye of the mynde, wherby, a man dothe directly thinke, what ſo euer he taketh to be ſo, or not ſo, it muſt nedes followe that the prophet meaneth it of that ſence of his thinking, wherin he thinketh directly, what ſo euer he dothe thinke. For if he hadde in that ſence of his thinkinge, that there were a god: doubtleſſe the prophette wolde not haue ſayde of hym this, that there is no god in his ſight, whiche is as much to ſay, as there is no god in his meaning, or ſo farre as he doth directly thinke, wherfore clere it is, that he denieth god in his hart directly.

sp.speaker: CATHO.
sp.p:
That foloweth not, for thou muſte conſider, what the prophette ſaythe alſo of hym, but a litle after in the ſame pſalme,Pſal. 9. which thou doeſt allege, wherin his wordes be theſe, Dixit in corde ſuo oblitus eſt deus, auertit fuciam ſuam ne videat in finem, that is
to ſay, he ſayde in his hart, god hath for gotten, he turneth away his face, and will neuer ſee it. Alſo a litle after that, the prophet inueieth farder againſt him, with this queſtion, Propter quid irritauit impius deum? dixit enim in corde ſuo non requiret, whiche is this muche to ſay, why dothe the taityfe attempt or prouoke god? for he ſayth in his hart, he will not looke vpon it. Now by theſe wordes of the prophet, thou maiſte perceue ageyne, that he meaneth it not of this felowes deniall in his herte directly, but of his deniall conſequentlie. for if the fooliſhe fellowe hadde thoughte in his herte there hadde bene no god directly in deede, hee wolde not haue ſaide in his hart, that god hath forgotten, and that he turneth awaie his face and will neuer looke vpon it. For that which is not, can do none of all thoſe thinges or any other lyke. Therfore he did not ſaie in his hart directly, ther is no god, but yet he ſaide it conſequently, that is to ſaie, he conceiued (as euery heretyke doeth) ſuche thingꝭ in his hart directlie, wherof it muſte nedes folowe, that there is no god conſequentlie. Wherfore, ſo doth the prophet meane, and none otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: Syr herein ye be deceued, for this is not that fooliſhe fellow, which the prophette ſpake of before. But in very deede, it is an other, as it appereth plaine by the prophetꝭ wordꝭ, whiche doth clerely ſhow, that the one doth ſay in his hart, there is no god, and the other the contrary.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
That is not trew, for the contrary is to ſay in his harte, there is a god, but he ſayth not ſo, for in his harte he ſayeth no more but that god hath forgotten, and will neuer looke vpon it, which is as muthe to ſaie as this, that god is not iuſt. As he were not, if he wold other forget, or neuer looke vpon the puniſhemente of iniquitee.
And therfore the prophet doth ſay, there is no god in his ſight, becauſe he ſeeth no iuſtice in god: whereof (if there were none, as he iudgeth in his herte) it muſt nedes folowe, that there were no god in dede: as there is not in the conſequence of that he ſaithe in his herte. Wherfore this place of the prophet doth but expounde and declare the other.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: No ſyr not ſo, for the conſequent deniall of god, is diſcribed in this place, whiche you do here nowe allege. And the directe deniall of god, in the other two places alleged before.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Let it ſo be: I wyll not greatly ſticke with the therein, ſith the deſcripcions of them bothe be ſuche, as declareth the conſequent deniall, to be at the leaſt, as euill as the other is.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: That I denie againe. For the ſcripture: of as many as be of his ſorte, whiche ſaithe in his herte, there is no god, dooeth plainly ſaie, they are corrupte, and become abhominable in their fantaſies.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Then take this with all,Pſal. 13. that of as many as be of his ſorte, in whoſe ſight (as the ſcripture doe ſaie) there is no god, it ſaith alſo, their waies are euer more,Pſal. 9. filthy, polluted, or corrupted: and what maketh any ſorte abhominable, but onely ſuche waies?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Yea but the ſcripture in bothe thoſe places, dooeth ſpeake onely of them, whiche denieth god directely, and not of them, whiche bee of his ſorte, that ſaith in his herte,Pſal. 9. god hath forgotten. &c. And therin denieth hym not, but conſequently.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: What if I graunte the ſame? yet thou muſt marke as well what it ſaith alſo of that ſorte, as of the other before, although they denie hym not (as thou ſaieſt) but conſequently.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
Theſe be the wordes, Epurge domine deus, Pſal. 9. & exaltetur manus tua, ne obliuiſcaris pauperum. O lorde god (he crieth) ariſe, and
lyfte vp thy hande, and forget not the poore.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: What is this to them?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: More (I maie tell the) then all that is alleged before, is to the other. For the prophet knowyng the curſed iniquitee of theſe that denieth god but conſequently to be ſuche, and ſo muche more gretter then could be expreſſed with any direct, proper or ſpeciall wordes, was compelled to declare it, with onely exclamacion ageine them to god, for lacke of any other ſufficient waie or meane to expreſſe it by.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Then, if the prophet ſo mēt it agein them as ye ſaie, why doth he adde vnto it this, forget not the poore?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Becauſe theſe are, to the poore, the greatteſt perill and peſtilent plage, that euer was or is poſſible to come amonge them. In ſo muche, that if god wolde permitte and ſuffre them to continewe, thei wolde not faile, if it were poſſible to de •• roy and deuoure them all:Math. 24. And therfore the prophet doth exclame and crie vnto god, to lifte vp his hande to ouerthrowe theim, that the poore might eſcape their miſcheuous indeuor, and wicked purpoſe.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: whiche poore are thei?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
The poore in lernyng, the poore in knowlage, vnderſtandyng, & iudgement, ſpecially of diuine miſteries. The poore alſo in their owne conceite: the poore in ſpirite, of whom it is written, beati pauperes ſpiritu, Math. • . bleſſed are the poore in ſpirite: ſo poore, as knowth nothyng of their own, remē bryng alwaie theſe woordes of thapoſtle,1. Cor. 4. quid habes ꝙ non accepiſti? what haſt thou (he ſeith) that thou haſt not receiued? & therfore ſo poore, as cauſeth them, neuer to ceſſe beggyng & crauyng of god, in whō (thei know) conſiſteth all the whole helpe & ſuccour of their pouerte: wherin, dwelleth ſuch a number, and ſo many, as moueth the holy prophet of veri pitee, to exclame (as I ſaid) and crie
vnto god, for their defence and deliuerance, (among all other) from theſe, moſt ſpecially, which denieth not god, but conſequently. For of the other, this poore, can muche better beware then thei can of theſe, for the ſecret behauour of their miſchiefe, whiche is muche more open in the other, and therfore leſſe perelous. wherfore, thus it maie well apere, that to denie god but conſequently, is at the leaſt no leſſe euill then it is to denie him directly.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Syr I wyll omit, for a while, what ſo euer I haue more to ſaie herein to the coutrary. And in the meane tyme I wold yet be anſwered to this my queſtion, how it may be (as you ſaie it is) that an heretike doth denie the trewth of thoſe articles, whiche he doth ſo directly graunt & confeſſe, ye and more ouer, vtterly beleue and thinke therin as he ſaith.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: haſt thou not forgotten that yet.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: No mary ſyr, for there hath ben nothynge hitherto that maketh more ageinſt ye pith of your purpos, thē that doth.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Then for the ſolucion therof, thou canſt not ſaie naie, but nowe thou ſeeſt a manifeſte difference of theſe two denials, wherof the one is directe, and the other conſequent.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: All that I perceiue well enough.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Therfore if thou beare that well in minde, thou ſhalt ſe thy doubte therby, clene put awaie. For whan an heretike denieth the trewth of ſome parte of the faithe directely, and the ſame trewthe (as it is proued before) is no more, no leſſe, or none other in any parte therof or in all together, then it is in the ſame parte whiche he doth directely denie, this muſte nedes folowe, that he denieth the trewthe of all the reſte conſequently.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p:
Syr then for example, take thaſcencion, for one of the articles, whiche an heretike dothe directly graunte
and confeſſe.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Contente.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Therfore when he doth graunt and confeſſe the aſſencion directely, ye wyll not denie but that he doth graunt and confeſſe the trewth therof.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Yea but how?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Mary directly.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: yea and yet the ſame trewth I ſay, he denieth conſequently for all that: becauſe he denieth it, in ſome other article directly, for els he were no heretike at all.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Then he dooeth graunte and denie one thynge bothe at once.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Yea, directly and conſequently?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Howe can that be?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: In dede very ſildom in a iuſt man, I maie ſaie to the.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: In whom then?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: In an heretyke veray communely.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: How ſo?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Becauſe the articles of the faithe be diuerſe and many: And the trewthe of them all, but one.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: What is that to this purpoſe?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: not nothyng, if thou conſider a difference betwene them, and the trewthe that is in them.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Wherby ſhuld I conſider a difference betwene them, and the trewthe that is in them, when there is no article, that can be without trewth?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Yet thou maieſt well conſider it by this, that if there were not a difference, betwene euery article of the faithe, and the trewthe whiche is in eache of them, there ſhuld be other ſo many diuerſe trewthes, as there be articles, (which are many in dede) or els ſo fewe articles, as there be trewthes, which is but one. wherfore this well conſidered, it maie ſone appere how an heretike doth graunt and deny one thynge both at once. That is to ſaie, graunt it directly, and denie it conſequently, as he doth in what ſo euer article he doth graunt: & that thou maiſt the better perceiue it, ſuppoſe an heretike, which graūteth the paſſion of Chriſte, & denieth his reſurreccion, as ſome of them did in time paſte.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Agreede.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Then when he graunteth the trewth of the paſſion directly, doth he not denie the very ſame trewth conſequently, in that he denieth it in the reſurrection directly? for when both thoſe articles (as al the reſt) haue but one very ſimple and ſingle trewthe, which is in each of them, how can the ſame trewthe bee denied in the one article directly, but that it muſte therfore be alſo denied, as well in the other conſequently? as in cace, if thou were now in diuerſe places at once, as the trewth is in diuerſe articles, how coulde I denie the, in this place to be a man, but that I muſt therin, denie the to be the ſame, as well in all other places, where ſo euer thou arte beſide? how be it, in this place directly, and by reaſon of that, in all other places, conſequently. For the direct deniall of a thing to be the ſame that it is, muſte nedes folowe the thing, wherſoeuer it be. For one thing denied and not denied both at once, in reſpect of it ſelfe, can neuer be. And therfore no more can trewth, whiche is but one.

sp.speaker: HE.
sp.p: Sir yet as I do now perceue, in reſpect of the two ſondry articles wherin it is, it may bee.

sp.speaker: CA.
sp.p:
Ye but not in both directly, for thou muſt yet farder conſider that this direct denial, runneth not onely, to wher or wherin, but alſo to what the thing is, which is in, for it is two thingꝭ to denie wherin a thinge is, and to deny, what the thinge is, as if I denie thy ſoule to be in thy hand, yet it foloweth not, that I denie it to be in thy foote, or in any other member of thy body beſide, becauſe that deniall runneth not, but onely to where or wherin it is, but if I take occaſion of thy hand to denie thy ſoule whiche is in it. And therin deny it directly to be the ſame that it is (as euery heretike taketh occaſion of one article or other to deny the trewth that is in it, and therin denieth it to bee
the ſame that it is) it muſt therfore nedes folowe, that I denie thy ſoule, where, or wherin ſo euer it be, that is to ſay, as well in thy foote as in thy hande, and in euery other parte of thy body alſo, becauſe that deniall renneth not only (as I ſayd) to where or wherin, but alſo directly to what thy ſoul is, whiche is as well in euery ſenſible parte of thy body, as in thy hand, and all one. And therfore, although it be not directly denied, but in that parte onely, wherin the occaſion therof is taken, yet is it alſo conſequetly denied, wher ſo euer it is beſide. Wherfore euen ſuche is an heretikes deniall of the trewth, in what parte of the fayth ſo euer he denieth it, for his deniall renneth not onely to where or wherin the trewth is, but alſo directly, to the trewth it felfe. For that ſame trewthe he houldeth directly to be no trewth at all, which onely maketh hym an heretike. And therfore that ſame only trewth, once directly denied, can not be but denied (as I ſayd) where, or wherin ſo euer it be. How be it, directly in that parte, wherin the occaſion therof is taken, and conſequently in all and euery other parte wherin ſo euer it is beſide. Wherfore denied (as I ſaide) and not denied, in reſpect of it ſelfe, can not be defended or borne, by any diuerſitee of thinges, in how many ſo euer it be. For it is not poſſible that one very ſimple thing, beinge in deede directly denied, ſhoulde or might, by any meanes, all that while, be of the ſame denier verified or vndenied. And therfore this it may apere, how an heretike dothe denie the trewth of thoſe articles, whiche he doth graunt, that is (as I ſayd) graunt them directly and denie them conſequently.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Then can I ſay (I may tell you) euen as much of the other ſyde, for when ye ſay, that he denieth the trewth of the paſſion conſequently, in that he deniethe the trewthe of the reſurrection directlie. By the ſame reaſon, I ſay that he graunteth the trewth of the reſurrection conſequently, in that he graunteth the trewth of the paſſion directly.

sp.speaker: CA.
sp.p: That wil not follow, in hym ſpecially.

sp.speaker: HE.
sp.p: why not in him?

sp.speaker: CA.
sp.p: Becauſe he is an heretike.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: why wil it not followe in an heretike, as well as in an other man?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Becauſe, when an other man graunteth the trewth of the paſſion, or of any other parte of the faith directly, he graunteth therin the trewth of the reſurrection and alſo of all the other articles conſequently, & that not onely becauſe there is none other but the ſame trewth in the paſſion, that is in the reſurrection and in all the whole faithe thorowly, but alſo ſpecially, becauſe he denieth no parte of the faith directly: But when theretyke graunteth the trewth of the paſſion directlie, it can not ſo followe in hym, that he graunteth the trewth of the reſurrection conſequentlie, becauſe therin he denieth the ſame trewth directly, whiche doth reſiſte and exclude his conſequent graunte vtterly: and therfore thou maiſt not take the graunt of an heretike to be ſuch, as is the graunt of an other man, for they bee farre vnlyke.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Yet then by your ſaying, ſith the trewth of the paſſion, and the trewth of the reſurrection is but al one, that ſame one, doth he directlie graunt and denie both at once, which is playne contradiction.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
In dede it were no leſſe, if that ſame directe graunt, and direct deniall of the trewth, mette both together in one article, as they do not. But now becauſe the direct
graunte of the trewth is in one article. and the direct denial of the ſame in an other, therfore by that, the contradiction is cleane put a way. And all by reaſon of the diuerſite of the thingꝭ, wherin the trewth is ſo graunted and denied. Neuertheleſſe, although the ſame direct deniall of the trewth, can not mete and ioyne together, with the direct graunte thereof, in one article, yet in the ſame one truth of both tharticles, the direct deniall, crepeth ſo nere the direct graunt ſecretly, that it doth infect and poiſon it with the propre venem of it ſelfe conſequently for all that, and maketh the graunt of no efficacie, much like, as wher a wicked mother can not come hir ſelfe, ſhe ſendethe a doughter of hir owne, as euil or wors then ſhe: for a direct denial, is as a verie mother, of a deniall conſequent.

sp.speaker: HE.
sp.p: And euen ſo, is a direct graunte, of a graunte conſequent.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: That is to be taken, where a direct denial, maketh no impediment: for therof riſeth to an heretike, the ſame ſpecial priuilege to him only dew and conuenient, that what ſo euer he graunteth of the faith, as an other man doth directly, ther ſhall neuer growe and come vnto hym any profit therof finally. For the iuſte graunte of a thing directlie, doth neuer ſo much prfitte and ſet forwarde, as the deniall therof conſequentlie, doeth hurt hinder and plucke backeward: for if I graunt the to be an honeſt man directly. And after many wordꝭ thereof reherſed accordingly, yet if I ſaie thou vſeſte thy nighbours maliciouſly, & cleane ageinſt charite: do I not therin deny thine honeſtee conſequently? what profit therfore doth my graunt therin directly?

sp.speaker: HE.
sp.p: But little.

sp.speaker: CA.
sp.p:
Nay none at all, if thou marke it well, for howe can the
profyte or perfection of a thynge abide, where the trewth of it is in dede denied? and therfore although there be neuer ſo many articles graunted directely, yet it is not enough, excepte it be ſo prouided that none be denied conſequently: And that can neuer bee done iuſtly, ſo longe as any one of them is denied directly. For that is able to infecte them all (as I ſayde) with a deniall conſequently. Accordyng to the ſaiyng of ſaint Paule (before alleged) modicum fermentum totam maſſam corrumpit:
• 1 Cor. 5. a little leuen ſoureth the whole lumpe of dowe. Therfore (as thou maieſt nowe perceiue thy ſelfe) it can not folowe, that an heretike hath trewely in dede, any parte of the faithe, other becauſe he dothe directly confeſſe and thinke many articles therof to be trewe (for he doth no leſſe both ſaie and thinke of his owne faithe, wherin he is deceiued) Nor yet becauſe the more parte of trewe chriſten people, doth not thinke hym to erre in any more, then he doth directely denie. For farder then that (as I ſayde) littell do thei perceiue or conſider, becauſe of ſuche thyngꝭ, what muſt folowe, thei ſeldome loke after: For beyonde their ſenſes, fewe of them doth reache. And as for any ſecretes of nature, they are ſcant able to touche: What place therfore can their iudgement haue, in thynges ſupernaturall? Wherfore what ſo euer he or they dooe ſaie or thinke, or how ſo euer to any of them both, it dooeth ſeme and appere, take this neuer the leſſe for a ſuer concluſion, that euery heretike (although it be a thyng to him ſelfe incredible) is yet for all that, no leſſe then out of the trewthe, of all the whole faithe throughly. That is to ſaie out of it in parte before men: and out of it all together before god: with whom euery thynge doth appere, not as it ſe=meth, but as it is in dede.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Yet ſyr, if it appere before god, as it is in dede: then it appereth before hym, with this differens, that where as he denieth ſome parte directely, he denieth all the reſte but conſequently.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: And makeſt thou no more but a but of that.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: What ſhuld I make of it els?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Thou ſhuldeſt make of it this, that there is no difference betwene them at all, before god.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: What not betwene a directe deniall, and a deniall conſequent?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: No trewly.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Then are they both one.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: I graunt the ſame before hym.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: And not before men?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Becauſe men can not ſo come by them bothe, as god hath them before him.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Then if they be but one before god, and two diſtincte before men, other god, or men, doth take them otherwiſe then thei be in dede.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: No not ſo.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: Yes ſyr, for if thei be but one, they can not bee two: if they bee two, they can not bee ſo litle or fewe as one.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Therin thou art deceiued. For that whiche is but one in ſome reſpecte, may be two in an other reſpecte well enough: as thy bodie and thy ſoule are but one, in reſpecte of thy perſon. And yet they are two in reſpecte, of their diſtinct and proper natures. And therfore lykewyſe, although a directe deniall, & a deniall conſequent be two diſtinct before men, in reſpect of their knowlage. Yet thei come both to one before god in reſpecte of his knowlage, wherin there is nothyng conſequent, but all preſent,

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Then by that, he knoweth not all, that men doth knowe.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Wilt thou ſaie ſo?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: It ſemeth no leſſe by your ſaiyng.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Wherefore?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p:
If all thynges be preſent to hym, and nothynge
conſequent: howe can he knowe a conſequent, whan (if it be as you ſaie) there is no ſuche before hym, that is to wit in his knowlage. and yet in mens knowlage there is.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Men doth knowe the ſucceſſion of daies, howe one foloweth an other. And how they can not, but paſſe ouer the firſte, before they come to the next, as the ſondaie before mundaie, and mundaie before tweſdaie, and ſo forthe. Yet the daies do not ſo paſſe and ſuccede one after an other before god in his knowlage, as they do before men, and in their knowlage. For he doth not (as who ſaie) tary and looke after ſuche or ſuche a daie or tyme as men doe: but hath mundaie as ſoone as ſundaie, and tweſdaie as ſoone as mundaie, and ſo euen the laſte as ſone as the firſte, and all at once: And therfore what ſucceſſion can bee of them before hym?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Then euen as I ſayde before of a conſequent: if there be no ſucceſſion of theim before hym, he dooeth not knowe, that they ſeccede and folowe one an other, whiche men doothe knowe, and ſo by this, he knoweth not all that men knoweth.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
That foloweth not, for he doth moſt perfectly knowe: that they ſuccede one an other in reſpecte of their naturall cowrce, and of mens knowlage and vnderſtandyng therof: but not in reſpecte of his owne proper and infinite knowlage, wherin the laſte (as I ſayde) cometh not after the firſte, nor yet the firſte before the laſte: wherfore in reſpecte of that knowlage, the daies haue no ſucceſſion at all: And euen ſo in lyke maner, he knoweth a conſequent, to be in reſpecte of it ſelfe, as it is in the order of nature, and of mans vnderſtandyng and knowlage therof. but not in euery condicion ſo, in reſpecte of his owne proper & infinite knowlage, which paſſeth all: wherin (as I ſaide) there is nothyng before nor
after, preceding nor folowyng, firſt nor laſt, but all thingꝭ together at once, euen very preſent and premanent: and therfore how is it poſſible for a directe denial, & a deniall conſequent, to haue any difference betwene them there? ſith there is no difference betwene them here but onely, that the one foloweth the other? as when thou ſeeſt a ſeruant folowyng his maiſter. Although there be a differēce betwene their two motions in this reſpecte, that the one, which cometh after, foloweth the other, that goeth before in their owne proper being, Yet ther is no ſuch difference of before and after betwene them, in reſpecte of their beyng in thy ſight, whiche doth receiue, complet, and comprehende them both to gether at once. For therin, they haue nether before nor after, as thei haue in their owne proper beyng. For if thei had, thou ſhuldeſt not ſee them both at once, as thou doſt, but one after an other as they are.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: If I doe not ſee them as thei are, then my ſight in thē is deceiued.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
No not ſo, for thou ſeeſt thē, not only as thei are, in reſpecte of theyr being in them ſelfes, but alſo far otherwiſe then ſo, in reſpect of their beyng in thy ſight, for the behauor of their being in thē ſelfes is one thyng. And the behauor of their being in thy ſight, is an other. And that not onely becauſe the one is as who ſaie naturall & the other accidentall, but alſo becauſe that, whiche is ſucceſſiue and conſequent in the one beyng, is all together very preſēt in the other. For els, thou ſhuldeſt not (as I ſayde) ſee them both at once and euē to gether: wherfore ſith it may by this apere that the ſight of man is able in ſome kind of thingꝭ, as ſone to reche that, whiche foloweth & cometh after, as that which doth precede & goe before, & to ſee that, euen preſēt, which in it ſelfe is but cō ſequent: how muche more is the ſight of all mighty gods
moſte prouident and infinite knowlage, able ſo to do in any kynde of thing, what ſo euer it be? Therfore before hym (as I ſayd) there is no difference betwene the direct deniall goyng before, and the conſequente deniall whith commeth after. But as well the conſequente as the antecedent, are ther become, euen both lyke preſent, and therfore what difference betwene them in that reſpect? wherin reſteth the ſ • ertee, of moſte perfit iudgement.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Then if ther be no difference betwene them, but bothe one before God, it muſt nedes followe, that it ſhulde be as great a faut to denie any parte of the fayth conſequentlie, as it is to denie it directly.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Haſt thou ſpied that now?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: I haue ſpied this, that it foloweth of your ſaying.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: I tolde the as much before, if thou hadeſt marked it well.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: yet I can not beleue it, for all that.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: No can?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: No trewly.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Wherfore?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Becauſe then it were as good for an heretike, to denie all the whole faith directly, as to deny directly but the leaſte parte of it, when therin is denied (by your ſaying) all the reſt conſequentlie.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: I will not ſay, it were as good, but I will ſay, it were not ſo euill.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: what not ſo euill to denie all the partꝭ of the whole fayth directly as it is to deny directly but ſome of them?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: So I ſay, although the ſame ſome, were but one of them.

sp.speaker: HE.
sp.p: I thinke ther be very ſmal reaſon therin.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: How ſmal ſo euer thou take it, yet ſo great thou ſhalt find it.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: That wold I fayne ſee.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
Then ſuppoſe two heretikꝭ, of the which, one denieth all and euery part of the faith directly and the other derectly but
ſome, or one parte therof.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Contente.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Then thou muſt graunt me three thinges, which no man will denie.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: what are they?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: The firſt is, that the more euill any man doth, the wors he is. The ſeconde is, that euery mans euel, is other to the hurt of hym ſelfe only, or els to the hurt of hym ſelfe, and of other alſo: And the thirde is, that his euell, whiche extendeth to the hurt of other, is wors to him ſelf, thē is his euel which extendeth no farder then to the hurt of him ſelfe alone.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: To al theſe, I muſte nedes agree.

sp.speaker: CAT.
sp.p:
Then there is no doubt, but that heretike, whiche denieth but one parte of the faith directly, is a thouſand folde worſe, then the other is, whiche directlie denieth them all together. For howe coulde his euill that denieth them all together directly, hurt any mo but hym ſelfe? In ſo muche that if he woulde, how ſhulde he be hard? I will not ſay or aſke what good man, but what other heretike is there, beſide any one of the ſame ſorte, that wold abide the heryng of hym? yea what good chriſten man, wolde not be moued with a more thankfull mynde towarde god, for the gyfte and preſeruacion of his owne fayth, and with a more diligente reſpecte to the conſeruacion and keping therof, for that he ſeeth one ſo farre gone, as hath loſte his altogether in euery poynt? ſo that other folke ſhulde by hym, take rather good then hurt. But as touching the other heretike, which denieth directly but parte, looke how muche it is leſſe, that he directly denieth, ſo many mo ther be, that doth not perceue it. And the moe there bee, that doth not perceue it, the moe therewith bee the ſoner deceued. And the moe ther bee, that be therwith the ſooner deceued, tho moe catche hurte & be therwith infected And the mo ther be, that be
therwith infected, the more his euill muſt nedes bee, which is the cauſe of it. And beſide this, how hath any hereſies ben ſowed, multiplied, and increaced, ſo greatly among the people (as to many hath bene) but by hym, which ſemed to haue ſo muche of the fayth, that he was long thought, to lacke therof nothing at al? But yet he did for all that, As the lamentable euill, that folowed therof, did at length more and more, playnly declare: But by hym which denieth altogether, there coulde neuer any ſuche thing be brought about: for he (as I ſayd) is one, that no man wold here. Beleued therfore how coulde he be? if he coulde not be beleued, no man by him coulde be deceued, if no man by him could be deceued, clere it is that his euill, could hurt no moe but him ſelf, if his euell could hurt no moe but him ſelfe, farre wors is his euill, which hurteth not onely hym ſelfe but alſo many other beſide. And that doeth he, which directly denieth but parte.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Yet he that directly denieth all, and can hurt therfore, no man els, but him ſelfe alone, is yet as willing as the other is, to hurt as many as the other doth. Wherfore he muſt be as euill as the other is, becauſe his wilfull intencion therein is no leſſe.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
That folowith not, for when that euill intencion, which can not extende to the purpoſe thereof, for lacke of power or libertee to perfourme it with all, Can not bee ſo euill as that, which hath no reſtraint or lette of comminge vnto it, by reaſon wherof, it neuer fayleth to take effect: his euill muſt nedes bee worſe, which is able to extende, bothe to the hurte of him ſelf, and alſo of many other moe, then is his euill, which can extende no fardir, but onely to the hurt of him ſelfe, and of no man els: And therfore becauſe no man wich his owne euill
can hurte an other, but that he doth farder hurt hym ſelfe alſo in the ſame. And the euill of him, that denieth but one article or two, hurteth ſome tyme many thouſandes mo: It muſte therefore nedes folowe, that his euill, is euen to hym ſelfe, ſo muche worſe then is his, whiche directly denieth them all, whereby he hurteth no man els but hym ſelf a lone: excepte thou wilte ſaie of euill workers, the more miſchife they do, the leſſe euill it is to them ſelfes.

sp.speaker: HERET.
sp.p: Ye maie bee ſure I will not ſaie ſo.

sp.speaker: CATHO.
sp.p: Then euidently by this it maie well appere, that farre wors is he (as I ſayde) both to him ſelfe and alſo to other, whiche denieth but one perte of the faythe directly, then is he that directly denieth Chriſte him ſelfe, and altogether.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Then how may that agree with this, that the oftener Chriſt be denied, the more wickedneſſe (ye know) it is.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: That I graunt: But herein is no ſuch caſe.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: yes, and that will I proue, for he that denieth any one article of the feith, denieth the trewth therof. And he that denieth the trewthe thereof, denieth the trewth of Chriſt. And he that deniethe the trewth of Chriſt, denieth him. Therfore it muſte nedꝭ folow, that he which direttly denieth the trewth of Chriſt in many articles, denieth Chriſte therein more oftener then doeth he, whiche directly denieth it, but in one article or in two. Wherfore he that denieth directly moſt articles, muſte nedes be ſo much worſe, then the other is.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
That foloweth not, for the one denieth not the trewth of Chriſt in ſo many articles directly, but the
other denieth it in as many, conſeqently: And as euill it is to denie it conſequently, as it is to denie it directly, and ſo proued before. Therfore, as euill is he that denieth it directly but in one article alone, as is he, whiche denieth it directly in mo, or in all together. And beſide this, I ſai that none of them both, denieth the trewth any more but once. For as he that killeth a man with twenſtrokes, killeth hym not lykewiſe twentie tymes: but in very dede no more but once: And as muche doth he, that killeth hym at one ſtroke: ſo he that directly denieth the trewthe of chriſte in twentie articles, denieth it not twenty tymes becauſe of that: but euē very once in dede. And no leſſe doth he, that denieth it directly but in one article alone. For a thyng is not alwaie ſo many diuerſe times denied, as the deniall therof is vocally ſpoken, and outwardly expreſſed: for the voice wherby the deniall is ſhowed forthe, is not the very deniall it ſelfe, but onely a meane to ſhewe it by. For the deniall it ſelfe, whan the voice is gone and paſte, abideth ſtill within, all one and the very ſame, that it was euen then and alſo before, at the firſte. Therfore when there is none other denied in this article or in that, then there is in any other or in all the reſte, the deniyng of the trewthe in twentie articles, can no more make it twentie times denied, then the wrytynge of one ſentence in twentie places, doth make it twentie ſentences. For when the trewthe beynge but one in all articles, is once denied in one article alone, how many ſo euer of them beſide, be denied afterwarde, they make not ſo many denials of the trewthe that is in them, but they make (as it were) ſo many ſhewynges, reherſals, or repetitions of the ſame, and nothyng els. For when the very deniall of a thinge, doth conſiſte in the
mynde, & not in the voice, whiche is but an inſtrument to expreſſe it with all, & is not in dede (as I ſaide) the deniall it felfe. Clere it is, that the thyng being but one, can neuer be twiſe denied, excepte it be once graunted betwene. For otherwiſe, it is but one continuall, & not diuerſe & ſeuerall, although it be neuer ſo ofte expreſſed, or in ſo many thingꝭ or ſondry waies reherſed. For it is two thynges to ſhew the twentie times or in twenty thyngꝭ, what I denie, & to denie that twentie times, which I ſhew the. Becauſe in ye one, ther is twentie denials, & in the other but one.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: Yea but what ſaie you to this, that moſt men do thinke, euery thyng that is denied, to be ſo often denied, as they hyer the deniall therof expreſſed, & repreſented vnto their eares.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: That is no mattier, for therin conſider not they, whether it do ſtill continew and abide all one, as well whan it is not expreſſed and ſhewed forthe, but kepte before & after within, as whan it is moſt manifeſtly and openly diſcloſed.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Let it ſo be. But yet, what ſaith the goſpell?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: What ſaieſt thou?
Mary that Peter denied Chriſte thriſe, whiche is alſo cleane againſt this your ſaiyng.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
No not a whit. for his deniall was of an other kynde than this is. For of that could neuer folow no Chriſte, as there doth & muſt nedes doe of this: for that was in dede but feigned, reſtyng in wordes onely, and not in mynde: for although it ſemed, & ſo be ſaide (as right well it maie) that he denied Chriſte. Yet maie it be trewly ſome waie ſaide the contrary. For he denied but his owne knowlage of hym, and nothynge els. for it is two thynges for me to denie the, that is to ſaie, to denie what thou art, and to denie that I knowe the. Whiche kynde of deniall, no heretikes doth vſe, that is to wit, to denie that they knowe Chriſte: although
they might well enough, ſith they be of that ſorte, or farre wors,Math. 25. then to whom chriſte ſayth, I knowe not you. Neuertheleſſe, they do not ſo. For all the mainy of them, ſemeth to graunt hym, and no men in maner more: but yet for all that, they do in dede, denie, not that thei knowe hym, but that & what he is, which is ten times wors: For ſeint peter denied not what he was, but only that he knew hym. Whiche was but a feigned deniall, and did onely conſiſte in woordes. For it was farre otherwiſe in his mynde, becauſe he did both thinke & know that he knewe him well enough. And did for feare but feigne the contrary: wherfore all ſuch feigned denials, whiche hath there beyng not in minde but onely in wordes, may trewly be ſaid alwaie to be ſo many, as thei be ſondry times reherſed. But ſo may not this hereticall deniall, that we now ſpeake of. whiche is of an other ſorte, and doth reſt in the minde continually, muche more ſubtilly, muche more ſecretly, & therfore a thowſande folde more perilouſly, then is poſſible euen for the inuentours therof them ſelfes, to perceiue or thinke: And therfore all this conſidered, it is not harde for the to ſee, that the trewth beyng once denied in any one article alone, it is not the deniall in many or all the reſt of the articles afterwarde, that can make it euer the oftner denied by reaſon of that: when in that one, it ſtandeth ſo full in deniall before, that it can not be denied againe, excepte it be one (as I ſayde) graunted betwene: wherfore cleane againſt thine opinion, no oftener doth he denie the trewthe of Chriſte, whiche directly denieth al ye articles one after an other, then doth he which directly denieth but one alone. And what therfore canſt thou fynde els betwene them, but that he is yet as euill as the other, whom thou takeſt to be muche wors.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Euen this I can finde, that a faute can neuer be ſo euill, whan it is done vnwares and ignorantly, as when it is done, both ware & willyngly. And therfore he that denieth Chriſte but conſequently, doubtles denieth him vnwares and ignorantly againſt his wil. For with expreſſed wordꝭ, he doth both graunt & confeſſe hym plainly: but he, whiche denieth all tharticles directly (wherin he denieth him alſo with apparte wordes manifeſtly) denieth him euen very ware & willyngly, wherfore he muſte nedes be muche wors, then the other is.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Yea but how canſt thou proue, that he whiche denieth all the articles of the faithe directly, doth therin denie Chriſte bothe ware and willyngly, as thou ſaieſt he doth?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Howe ſaie ye that?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Thou haſt harde.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: In dede your queſtion therin maketh me nowe conſider with my ſelfe, that if I ſhulde take Ipon me to proue it, by his deniall of this article or that, euen frō the firſt to the laſte, ye wold ſay perchaūce, that he denieth hym but conſequently, and ſo vnware & ignorantly in any of them all. wherwith I wold holde my ſelfe, if it were not for this article of the Crede. I beleue in Ieſus Chriſte his onely ſonne. &c.

sp.speaker: CATHH.
sp.p: And thinkeſt thou, that any heretike doth directly denie that article?

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: That heretike whiche directly denieth all, muſt nedes therin, directly denie that. & therfore he denieth chriſt both ware & willingly.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Yea that heretike: But ther is none ſuch. For he that ſo doth, is not properly an heretike, but other a Pagan or Apoſtata, which is farder of, & more ſtrange vnto vs, then an heretike is.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: Then haue you loſt muche labor.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: why ſo?

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p:
what haue you done al this while, but gone about
to proue, that he, whiche denieth directlie hut one article of the faith, is wors then that heretike, which directly denieth them all together. And now ye ſey there is none ſuch?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: So I ſey, for ſuche an heretike, was and is, but in cace ſuppoſed, wherof, doeſt thou not ſee, what foloweth?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: What.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Euen this, that he which directly deuieth but one article of the faith, is farre wors then is a Pagan or Apoſtata. For when he is wors (as it is proued) then the other is, which directly denieth them all. And none directly denieth them all, but other a pagan or apoſtata, it muſte nedes followe, that he is wors, then any of them both.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: I praie you what call ye apoſtata?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: He that hath bene once a chriſten man, and yet hath vtterly forſaken the religion of chriſt ageyn, and is gone clene awaie to the pagans and foloweth them.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Trow ye ther be any ſuch?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Ther is no doubt of that.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Then ye graunt that he, and ſuche as he is, denieth Chriſt with a part wordes directly.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: What els?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Then he denieth him euen ware and wittingly.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
No trewly, for be thou right well aſſured, ther is no man liuinge that wolde denie Chriſt directly, if he wiſt, and were euen ware therin, what he denieth: For ſo ware is he what Chryſte is, which denieth hym directly, as he is ware, what the whole faith is, which denieth all that directlie. And ſo ware is he, what the whole faith is, which denieth all that directly, as he is ware, what one article of it is, which denieth directly but that alone: and that alone doth he not know, nor ſo muche as beleue nother. For ſuer it is, that if he dyd, he wolde neuer deny it: no more therfore doth he know or beleue the whole ſaith, nor Chriſt hym ſelf nother, which denieth both him
and it, directly altogether, what warneſſe or wittingnes therfore is there here, more in the one, then in the other? alſo there can no man be an heretike, but becauſe he denieth at the leaſt (as I ſayd) ſome one article of the faith or other. And that wolde he neuer do, but becauſe he beleueth vtterly that it is no parte of the fayth at all. wherof it folowith clerly, that if he knew it were, he wolde neuer denie it. Therfore looke what lacke, both of knowledge and alſo of beleue, he hath in one article, whiche directly denieth but that alone, & euen the very ſame hath he in both, which denieth twaine. And alſo in each of them likewiſe hath he, which denieth three. And ſo forth after the ſame ſorte, from one to an other, vntil it come to him which directly denieth Chriſt and all together. Therfore whē he that directly denieth Chriſt & al together, hath no more faith or knowlege of hym or it, then hath he, of that one article, which directlie denieth but yt ſame one alone, what more warely or wittingly doth the one, then the other, but euen both ignorantly together? And beſyde this, when the greatneſſe of fayth may be ſuch, as is of it ſelfe ſufficient and able to houlde and kepe, who ſo euer haue it, from the denying of Chriſt in euery condition. And when it is ſuer alſo, that the very knowlage of him is therto, much more able then that is. How clerly doth it follow therof, that who ſo euer denieth hym directly, neuer doth it ware and wittingly? wherfore notwithſtanding this, or any thing els, which thou haſte hitherto ſayd to the contrary, I will yet ſay as I ſaide (becauſe the trewth is ſo in dede) that as euell is he, which directly denieth but one article of the faith alone, as is he which directly denieth Chriſt him ſelf and all together, as euill I ſay, not in this or that reſpect, but vtterly in euery condicion. And
in diuerſe caces (as I haue declared vnto the) alſo much wors, both toward hym ſelfe and other alſo: This differens betwene them only except, that the contrary remaineth in the groſſe & ignorant iudgement of the commune ſorte.
