The cauſe wherof, I tolde the before (as it is in dede) euen to be this, that they are able to ſee and perceue (as they do) the whole euil of the one: and in compariſon therof, obſcurely ſo ſmal a parte of the other, that ſome taketh it more, ſome leſſe, ſum very little, & ſum no euil at al.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Sir, the daie (ye may ſee) is farre ſpente, and I haue yet a mile or twaine to go.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: A, now I perceue thow lackeſt matter, or els thou art wery of ſo muche talke.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Our talke hath laſted a great while.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: That is long of the, for if thou woldeſt haue bene content with enough, it had ben done, long eare this. But neuertheleſſe, to make an ende with all, Thou ſhalt haue my frendly aduiſe and counſaill, not only wel to remember, what I haue ſaid vnto the, concernyng the miſerable ſtate of this vnfeithfull and peruerſe generation. But alſo farder to conſider of what condicion and properte it is of. which (ſo long as it may endure) neuer ſeaſeth, to ſtudy, ſtriue, contēd, & feight agenſt that, which euer dyd, and euer ſhal, geue it the ouerthrow, and preuail ageinſt it,Math. 16. accordīg to this promiſe of chriſt, Porte inferi non preualebunt aduerſis eam, that is to ſay, the gatꝭ of hel, ſhal not preuaile ageinſt it.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Ageinſt what.

sp.speaker: CAT.
sp.p:
Ageinſt the holy catholike church, the pillare and ſtabilite of trewth,1. Timo. 3. as ſaint Paule doth cal it. of the which trewth, it is alſo written, Super omnia vincit veritas, Trewth preuaileth aboue al thingꝭ. yet not with
ſtanding al the ould experience herof, this peruerſe generacion, according to ther accuſtomed properte, nothing fearing the loſſe and caſting awey of them ſelues, hath ſturred vp (as all men knowith) ther damnable warre ageinſt this pyllare and ſtabilitee of trewth, euen nowe in our tyme ageine, as it hath done oft before, euen to ther own deſtruction. for ſuch doctrine of late thei haue here brought in and taught, as thei neuer were, nor yet are, nor neuer ſhalbe able to defend, by any kind of thing, only ſecular power except, as it hath apered manyfeſtly all redy: For, before they gate that of ther ſide, ther was nother holy ſcripture, nor ould auncient holy fathers, nor yet any ſcholaſticall lerning, that is to ſaie, any dewe and perfit order of reaſon, that could help, or make any thing for them. But of the other ſide, when they came once to power, and might, as they dyd, vſe that as they liſte, they were then ſo ſafe, (ſay al men what they wold) that it was neither holy ſcripture, nor nothinge els, that coulde preuaile ageinſt them: for what ſo euer argument came in ther handꝭ, they wold be ſuer to make the concluſion therof them ſelues, & that ſhuld be, other the porters lodge, the fleete, the marcialcy, the kingꝭ bench, the towre, or at the leaſt, ſuch attendance, as ſhuld make the reſpondent, ſpēd all, and more then he had: ye and ſomtyme, two or three of thoſe concluſions brought in, vpon one argument, and yet not ſo diſpatched nother: And therfore, doth not theſe and ſuch other concluſions, playnly declare the learning of ſuch diſputours, as can none otherwiſe finiſhe their argumentꝭ, but after that ſorte? May it not be ſaide, that theſe men be of a monſterous generacion? yes trewely although it were but for one thing (among many) that I do know.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: What one thing is that?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: It maie well be this, that there is no doute but good thei doe, or els the holy apoſtle wolde not haue ſaide,1. Cor. 11. Oporte hereſes eſſe, it is expedient (he ſaith, for hereſies ſo to be. And becauſe hereſies can not be, without heretikes. Therfore as expedient is the one as the other: and that were none of them both, excepte ſome profite riſe therof: wherfore good (I ſaie) they doe, and yet they neuer the better, how ſaieſt thou to that? For in dede, the more good they doe, the leſſe worthy of thanke they are: the leſſe worthy of thanke? Naie the more worthy of blame, whiche is more ſtrange. And therfore is it not as it were a monſtruous thinge in men to do good, and take no profite therof: ye to do good, and take moſte worthily hurte therof, and be wors then thei were before: In ſuch monſtruous feates, conſiſteth all the policie and cunnyng of this generacion. For they neuer ſpeake more trewly, then when they lie moſte falſely.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: How proue you that?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
It is ſone proued, and we goe but to this, that when they allege the wordes of the holy ſcripture moſte trewly, they doe yet denie the trewe meanyng therof vtterly. And what is a greatter liyng, then a falſe vnderſtandyng, and miſconſtruyng of holy ſcripture? Beſide this, their procedynges renneth directly againſt the dew order of their owne nature. Whiche nature, alwaie beginneth with the fleſhe, and endeth with the ſpirite. for the fleſhe at the firſte, is before the ſpirite. And the ſpirite at the laſte, is after the fleſhe, when they are once parted: But their procedynges contrarie wiſe, begynneth with the ſpirite, and endeth with the fleſſhe, as it doth now moſt plainly appere. For when they firſte brought forth their newelties, which wer ſuch & ſo ſtrāge,
as of the moſte parte, coulde not be knowen, where they founde them, or howe they came by them, And vpon requeſte made vnto them therof, thei anſwered alwaie and ſaide, we haue theim of the ſpirite: The ſpirit is the doer. The ſpirite is with vs, we haue the ſpirite, for why may not we haue the ſpirite, as wel as Peter or Paule? ſith it is writtē, Spiritus vbi vult ſpirat, Iohn. 3. the ſpirite worketh where he will, & therfore well to conclude, thei had the ſpirite: by reaſō wherof, to ſuch as obiected any thing to the contrary, and could not digeſt their doctrine. Thei alwaies anſwered in corners and ſaide, ye haue not the ſpirite. The ſpirite is not yet come vnto you: but haue a good hope, he will come well enough at lengthe, if ye bee willyng. &c. But nowe wold I faine know, where that ſpirite is become: for, although we harde of hym alwaie to much at the firſt, yet we here nothyng of hym nowe at the laſt: Therfore this muſt nedes be trew, yt other clene gone he is in dede, or els ſo ſhamefully turmoyled & ſowced in the fleſh, that he can no longer be iuſtly knowen, or caled by the name of a ſpirite, except he be (as there is no dowte but he is in dede) the very ſame ſpirite, whiche the holy prophet Oſee ſpeketh of, in his forthe chapiter,Oſee. 4. where he ſaith, Spiritus fornicacionū, decepit eos, That is to ſaie, the ſpirite of fornicacions hath deceiued them. wherfore, how there is this to be trew, that this is the ſpirit in dede, which thei ſpake of ſo much at the firſt, who hath ſo led thē all this while, yt now thei are aſhamed to confeſſe him at the laſt, excepte it be where thei hied him wt lacke of their wordes, & confeſſe him openly, with their manifeſt workꝭ. Therfore if any man dout of this trewth, let him but iuſtly waie & conſider the manifeſt voluptuous & fleſhly concluſion of all their procedingꝭ hitherto, & he ſhal
ſee it more plaine, then can be denied. For what hath all their practiſes finally tended vnto, but only to ye luſt of the fleſh, & ſuch other thyngꝭ as maketh for the ſame? among the whiche, although I can fynde no miracles of their doingꝭ, to defende their doctrine with all: yet I can finde ſome great meruails of their doingꝭ, to declare it withal.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: What be thoſe?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
Of diuers & many, I will ſhew the ſome, wherof this is one. Amōg their maried prieſtes, diuers there be, which haue lerned ſuch a cūning of their ſpirite, yt thei haue taught their yōg maried wiues of .iiii. or .v. yeres olde, to brynge them furthe children, of .xvi. or .xvii. yere olde. Whiche is a meruaile, becauſe it is worthy to be meruailed at, or wō dered vpon, thoſe the whether: And beſide this: an other meruaile I take it to be, that thei haue brought many of their children to ſuche a knowlage & vnderſtandyng, that through the helpe of their ſpirite, the doughter may trewly ſaie to her mother, I haue bene longer a maiden, then ye haue bene a wyfe, by a doſyne yeres: whiche is a meruailous thing alſo, as thou woldſt not faile to ſay thy ſelfe, if thou mighteſt come to the heryng therof. Therfore is it not an other meruaile, to ſee what a lacke, that woman hath, of the ſpirite of trewthe in this cace? for if ſhe had hym, ſhe might ſoone anſwere hir doughter, and ſaie, doughter thou art therin not a litle deceiued. For if all the trewth herof, were ſo well known vnto the, as it is to ſome other, thou ſhouldeſt fynde that I am yet hitherto, no very wyfe in dede, although I be thy mother. And therfore thy conpariſon herin can not holde: Nowe conſider with thy ſelfe, whether theſe be ſtrange maruels
or no. Nuertheleſſe, although theſe meruailes and many other lyke, do playnly declare vnto vs, what maner of generacion this is. Yet we haue a more ſpeciall token and marke to knowe them by, then all this cometh to: And that apointed vnto vs for the ſame purpoſe, by our ſauiour Chriſte hym ſelfe, where he ſaith, A fructibus eorum cognoſceris eos, Math. 7. by theyr fruites ye ſhall knowe theim.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Nay then ſyr if ye go to that, I muſt nedes ſai more then I thought to do. For ye haue here declared their frutes alredie, as in dede thei declared yours, from their beginnyng hetherto, alleged the ſame texte to be mente and ſpoken of you, and not of them: who, therwith, ſo peinted your petegrew in dede, that a man might be aſhamed to here it.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: ye to here their ſhamefull peintyng of their lacke of charitee.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Nay to here of your frutes, as they declared them.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: What frutes of ours, did thei declare.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Your pompe, pride, ambicion, malice, enuie, cupiditee, glotony, lupurious liuyng, and ſo forth, with many other vices, mo then the time will ſerue mee now to reherſe.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
Why all theſe be but the comune frutes of mās fraile pronitee. And neuer faileth to be found in ſome perſons, amonge all ſortes of men, in euery countrey, where ſo euer are any people at all. And therfore although they leied all theſe frutes to our charges, yet are they no more ours, then thei be theirs. But in dede the trewthe to ſay, when obſtinate errour began to riſe, & ſought about euen for thē, his own moſt apte & very proper inſtrumentes, he found thē in dede, euen amonge vs. Where thei had digged
farre more depelie, in the planting, graffing, and gatheryng, of all theſe fruictes, then euer did we. And therfore he cauſed them, as his owne, moſte mete ond apte for his purpoſe,1 Iohn. 2. to depart from vs, according to the wordꝭ of ſaint Iohn, where he ſaieth, Ex nobis prodierunt, ſed non erant ex nobis, nam ſi fuiſſent ex nobis, permanſiſſent vtique nobiſcum, That is to ſaie, they went out from vs, but they were not of vs, for if they had bene of vs, they ſhulde haue remained verily with vs: Wherfore trew it is, that they went out from vs, and not we from them, with whom we were neuer, for we are now, euen where we were alwaie, and ſo are not they. Therfore ſith it is plaine and manifeſt, that their departure from vs, was not of charitee, it muſt nedes be as playne and manifeſte againe, that it was of the contrary, which is none other but euen mere malice in dede. and that was it, that cauſed them, to taunte vs with thoſe euill fructes which are commone, to thintent they might therby, hyde the reſte of their owne, which are to them, euen propre and ſpeciall: for they be not, the commone euill fruictes of men, which our ſauiour Chriſt taught vs to know this ſpeciall generation by: for then we hadde bene therof neuer the nere. becauſe a commune ſigne or token, can geue no certaine or ſpeciall knowlage of any ſingular thing. Wherfore, becauſe this kinde of men, is ſo ſingular, as ther is no moe ſuche, (although to many by that) Chriſt gaue vs therfore, a ſpeciall note and token to know them by, when he ſaieth, ye ſhall know them by their fruictes.Math. 7. That is to ſay, by thoſe fruictes, which are there owne propre vnto them ſelues, and to no men els. For (as who ſaieth) otherwiſe, ye could not diſcerne them from any other fortꝭ of men, where as by thoſe
fruictes, which I meane, ye ſhal not miſſe to know them in dede.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: What propre fruictes of their owne haue thei, that no man hath els beſide?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Canſt thou not tell?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: No not yet.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
Then will I tell the my ſelfe, although not all, becauſe I can not: nor yet ſo many as I can, becauſe it nedeth not. But neuertheleſſe, ſome of them, becauſe the purpoſe requireth it: And therfore doſt thou not knowe, that thei went alwaie about, to bring vs in to thexperience of this trew ſaying, Vbi nullus or do, ibi ſempiternus horror?Iob. 10. which may this be engliſhed, Where is no order, there is continual feare, trembling, aſtoniſhment, aduerſitee, or thraldome. And therfore what order lefte they (I meane not in prophane places, but in no leſſe then in the holy houſe of god, wherin order ought to be moſte regarded and moſte conſtantly houlden and kept) what order (I ſaie) lefte they therin vnſhaken, or vnouerthrowen al together? And that not onely by them ſelues, of their owne dedꝭ in ſome places, but alſo by their deceuable and falſe perſwaſions in all places. For was it not they only, that cried awaie with al the olde auncient cerimonies of the churche? and that ſo longe, vntill they had therin preuailed and brought it to pas? And ſone after, went thei not about to play the ſame parte, with all the holy ſacramentꝭ likewiſe, only two except, ſaieng there was no mo of them ſacramentꝭ in dede, but only two? & yet of thoſe two, they could not abide ſo muche as the trewth, and very right vſe of them • other. Farthermore, who deuiſed the newe alteration of the diuine ſeruiſe, but they? And when they had done it, I praie the what was it? any other or better then ſuche, as
coulde not content them ſelues two yeres together? And therin to ſhow how lothe they were, in any thing to agree with vs, where we had the Pater noſter, before the Creede, they put the Creede before the Pater noſter: A worthy occaſion, of ſuch an alteracion. Therfore how newfangled fā ſes reigneth amonge them, Their handling of their (Communion table) doth plainly declare: for how hath that ben toſſed from poſte to pillare, now eaſt, now weaſt, nowe north, now ſouth, now vp, now down, this way and that wai, & ſildome in reſt? In ſo much that in many places, the chauncel could not holde it, but downe it went, into the body of the churche, to drawe ſomewhat nere the doore: where as men ſaie, it had gone out and cleane awaie, if thei had bē ſuffered but a little while longer. Wherfore, if newfangled faſſions, be contrary and ageynſt the dew order of any honeſt mannes houſe, as thei be in dede: how much more then, are thei contrary and ageinſt the dew & honorable order, of the holy houſe of god? how be it, by thē we maie ſee, what maner of headꝭ theſe be, from whence they come: which ſpareth not in matter & place of ſo great weight, to ſet forth, theſe fruictes of their owne malitious and propre deceit: For to whom maie we trewly aſcribe, the gret ſpoiling and defaſing of our churches, but only to theſe newfangled miniſters, of ſuch fals doctrine, as we ſee plaine, hath brought it to paſſe? for who had ani ſuche maner of cōſcience, as durſt once to venture vpō it, but only theſe deniers of truth, & ſuch other as thei deceued? who could haue thought it to be wel done (as I thinke ſome did, or els thei wold not haue done it) but throw the falfe prechinges & other moſte crafty allurementes, of tbis peruers generaciō? who be they, that bareth to Chriſt, ſuch a ſecrete loue, and an inward zeale in their hartes, that thei
can not ſuffre the picture or Image of his bleſſed body, to ſtande in their ſightꝭ? Who be thei, that went downe with the armes of his holy paſſiō, & in the place therof, vp with the armes of men? who be thei, that put aweie, the holy ſigne of the croſſe, as euill or vnprofitable to looke vpon: And to ſupply the place therof, brought in Lyons, dogges and dragons, as good and more mete for vs to beholde? who be they (I ſay) that are and were, the doers and workers of all theſe thynges with many other lyke, but only theſe very ſataniſticall teachers through their ſubtill pernicious & moſt falſe perſwaſions?

sp.speaker: HE.
sp.p: Syr that thei did, thei did it by a lawe.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
wilt thou tell me that tale? when theſe be neither the makers, nor yet the folowers, but alwaies the chiefe and manifeſt breakers of lawes, ſo farre as in thē lieth? For what lawes, ſtatutes, or orders, hath ben made, ſo ſtronge, ſo good, and ſo profitable, for the ſpirituall comune welthe in eſpeciall, as thei haue not broken, and cauſed to be broken, contemned and deſpiſed, ſo far as they might, for feare or ſhame? Therfore tell not me of their obſeruyng of lawes, againſte the whiche, thei haue ben ſo many waies, open perſwaders. In ſo much that I my ſelfe, haue herd ſome of thē in the pulpit ſay, that thei wold go before the law, & bid the law, come after lyke a daw. And euen ſo thei did in dede: For tel me by what law, wēt thei down with ye roode & the roode loftꝭ to the great defaſyng of churches? By what law, wēt thei downe with the holy alters of god, to the deſperaciō of many, in that thei had well beleued before? By what lawe wente they downe, with twentie thynges moe, then the tyme wyll nowe ſerue to reherce? Therfore theſe be not thoſe, that wolde folowe the lawes. But they be thoſe, that wolde haue the lawes folowe them. And
then ſhulde they be no lawes at all, but only ſuch, as thei wolde make them ſelues. For this by reaſon thou maieſt well know, that thoſe, whoſe religion conſiſteth in the deniall of trewthe, as the religion of heretikes doth, can neuer awaie with their lawes, whoſe religion conſiſteth in the profeſſion and graunt of trewth, as ours doth. And therfore, what maner of lawes thoſe wold be, which theſe deniers of trewthe, wolde other make or folowe, if they might haue their wyll, it is not harde to perceiue: But to be ſhorte in this cace, what is amiſſe in all this lande, other by reaſon of any innouaciōs, alteracions, confuſiōs, or otherwiſe, wherwith the moſte parte of the people are thiefly greued, but that hath riſen & ſo come to paſſe, only by theſe extreme enemies of truth, & their crafty meanes?

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: Crafty meanes? what meanes are they.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
Their fals doctrine, falſe teachyng, falſe preachyng, diſſimulacion, fraudulent flatteryng, crafty liyng, feigned holines, promiſe of trewthe and paiment of falſhede, promiſe of peace, and payment of diſcorde, promiſe of truſte and paiment of deceite, pretence of vertue & performans of vice, and ſuche other meanes, as are neuer to ſeke, nor out of vſe, with theſe moſte capitall enemies of trewthe: in ſo muche, that if thou were not a man ſo blinded withaffection toward them as thou arte, Thou ſhuldeſt clerely perceiue & ſee, all theſe meanes with many other lyke, in commune practiſe among them daily: And therfore, is it harde to conſider & vnderſtande, what kynde of fruites they are, whiche are alwai procured by theſe meanes, and many ſuch other as theſe bee? I paſſe ouer their handlyng of the wyls and teſtamentes of men, becauſe I ſee them ſo ſtrangely handle the moſt holy wyll & teſtament of chriſte: for how much of that will, wold thei haue trewly
performed and kepte? Thei ſaie them ſelfes, no leſſe then all: And yet we maie perceiue, thei mene in effecte, nothynge at all. Neuertheleſſe they wolde haue all thynges referred wholly and onely to that wyll, to thentent they might then, waie all thynges them ſelfes, euen after their owne wyll. Thinkyng therby, that their yea, and our nay, and our yea, and their nay, ſhuld ſtande together vpon an euen groūde: for although thei be in number far to many, & yet but few, in compariſon of all other men: Neuertheleſſe in matters of the churche, whiche be not ſmall, but greatteſt of all, looke what all other men wolde, thei will not: what all other commende, they diſpraiſe: what all other diſpraiſe, thei commende: what al other do graunt, thei denie: what all other do loue, they do hate: what all other ſet forwarde, they wolde plucke backewarde: what meane thei by this? May thei not be called a peruerſe generacion?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: It is a generacion that beareth ſome lies nowe and then.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
In dede as thou ſaieſt. one I confeſſe my ſelfe. For where they bee ſayde to leape from hereſie into treaſon, although it were but a ſory leape, yet the reporte therof is not trewe. For they haue not ſo leide hande vpon treaſon, that they haue therein lefte their hereſie, as the reporte doth ſownde: But in dede not leauynge the one for the other, they haue ſo wrought them both to gether, that thoſe, whiche neuer tooke in hande, but one of them alone, can not yet bee compared vnto theym, in any of them bothe: wherfore, they bee vntrewly reported to leape out of hereſie, into treaſon, when they wyll be ſuer to kepe them together, in a truſte that the one ſhall helpe the other: Therfore what wonder is it, although they rebell againſt their gouernours here in earthe, when they
be ſuche very rebellions againſt the trewthe of almighty god in heauen?Iob. 10. Pſall. 21. How haue thei handled the ſemeles garment of Chriſte? not caſtynge lottes for the whole, (as his perſecutours did) to ſaue the vnitee therof: But a thouſande folde wors, ſnatchyng at the partes therof, to tere, rent, & diſtroy it all together. For what diſſencion, diuiſion, diſcorde, ſtrife, contencion & diſtraction of vnite • and concorde, they haue made in chriſtes holy churche, all the worlde doth knowe.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: I meruaile what is to be founde, amonge them, that ye wyll take in good parte.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
Truſt me trewly, euen as much, as in them is worthy: whiche (without queſtion) in reſpecte of thende, they applie it vnto, is nothyng at all: For how bitter thei make (or take) the ſwete yoke of chriſte: And how heuy, they make (or take) his light burthen alſo,Math. 11. it doth well appere, not onely by this, that they haue ſo cleane, ſhake them both of, and caſte them away for their owne partes: but alſo by this, that they haue cauſed, ſo many other, to doe the ſame lykewiſe: for are they not, the manifeſte enemies of chaſtitee? The perſwaders of fleſhly libertee? The breakers of holy vowes? The contemners of vertuous abſtinence? The crafty ſecret enticers from praier, when they call it but liplabour? For what haue the done, vnder pretence of commune praier, but brought the moſt parte of the people, from their deuoute perticular, and ſpeciall praiers? Alſo what a malicious & ſpitefull parte haue they plaied, with no leſſe than our bleſſed lady mother of our ſauiour chriſte, and with his holy apoſtles, martyrs, confeſſors, & all the holy compenie of heuen? Any other then done what they can, to bryng them all, euen out of regarde, out of eſtimacion, yea and cleane out of memorie? as it is of the prophet ſayde vnto god:
Cogitauerunt aduerſus ſanctos tuos, dixerunt, Pſal. 82. venite, et diſperdamꝰ eos de gente, & non memoretur nomē Iſrael vltra. Thei ſtudied (he ſaith) againſt thy ſaintꝭ. They ſaide, come, let vs ridde them awaie from the nacion, and let not the name of Iſraell, that is to ſaie, the name of ye beholders of god, be had any longer in memory.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: Syr, this was ſpoken of them in thoſe daies, whiche were againſt all thoſe ſaintes, that were then but here in earthe.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
Thou ſaieſt well, and therfore howe much more was it ſpoken, prophetically of theſe in our daies, whiche are againſt all thoſe ſaintes that are nowe in heauen? amonge whom, they ſpare not ſo much, as the moſte dere mother of Chriſte. For why haue they wyped ſo cleane awaie, all theyr names out of the letanie? why haue they done the ſame likewiſe out of the kalender, as in other places beſide, and that very many? Why haue they made awaie, with all their images, out of the churches? And that with more ſpite, then I can expreſſe? And therfore what is the cauſe that theſe hippocriticall teachers hath done all this, but onely, vnder their falfe pretence of auoidynge idolatry, to put bothe them, and their names, euen cleane out of memory? as though it were good and beſte for vs, neuer to haue them in mynde: And ſo in a whyle not to beleue, that euer there were any ſuche. To this, their teachyng and doynge doth vtterly tende. But herein, what dooe they els, but ſhewe theim ſelfes ſo farre exiled out of the number of that holie companie, That, to come therto, they haue no token or lykelihode of any poſſibilitee? Wherfore, ſo muche of their purpoſe, as they haue brought to paſſe all ready, maie put vs, euen cleane out of doubte, what they wolde dooe in
the reſte, if they had tyme and libertee. Any other thinkeſt thou, but ouerthrow all? Therfore to what ſorte of men, may this kinde of fruictes, with many other like, be iuſtly aſcribed, but only to this vnfeithfull generacion alone? According to theſe foreſaid wordꝭ of our ſauiour Chriſt, Ex fructibus eorum cognoſcetes eos, By their fruictes (he ſaieth) ye ſhall knowe them.Math. 7. For doubtleſſe theſe fruictes, procedeth not of mans commune frailtee, but in very dede, of a diabolicall peruerſitee: for without queſtion theſe men be of that ſorte, of whom ſaint Paule doth ſaie, Confitentur ſe noſſe deum, factis autem negant, Titu. •
cum ſint abominati et increduli, which maie this be engliſhed, They ſaie, they know god, but in their doynges, they deny him, when they be abominable and vnfeithfull: Therfore ſith it maie alſo now apere, by the teſtimonie of this holy apoſtle, that they be abominable in their workꝭ, and falſe in their faith, what remaineth in them, wherby ſo many (as we ſee) hath bene trained in to their falſe fraternitee,
• Cori. 11. but onely their craftie, ſubtil, feyned, vnfruictfull, and bare fantaſticall wordes, with out trewth or honeſtee? For there can be no trewth in vnfeithfulneſſe, nor yet honeſty, in abominaciō, by the which two termes, that is to ſaie, by vnfaithfulnes & abomination, the holy apoſtle (as thou ſeeſt) doth here deſcribe thē: Wherfore, conſider with thy ſelfe, what a lamentable fortune, & miſerable chaunce haue thei, which hath & yet doth commit the leading, of no leſſe then their owne ſoules, vnto ſuch a peruers generacion, ſuch a peruers generaciō I ſaie, as hath diſſented and ſtraied awaie, not onely from the commendable doynges, of all good chriſten people: but alſo from the pure veritee and trewth of Ieſu Chriſt, And hath brought them ſelues, in to ſuche an vnfeithful,
and abominable ſtate, as thou maiſte nowe perceue, not only by ſo much as I haue declared vnto the alredy, but alſo, by the manifeſt wordes of tholy apoſtle hym ſelfe, whiche doth ſaie, they are both abominable, and alſo vnfeithfull: And therfore, who be they, that yet doeth folow them? any other but ſuch, as therin, are moſte infortunate? and what hath brought them to that infortunitee? any thing more, then that lacke of grace,Prou. 16. whiche cauſeth a certayne waie that leadeth to perdiction, to ſeme very ſtreight? More euer what do they finde in thoſe leders whiche cauſeth them to be ſuch folowers? any truth of faith, when the apoſtle doth ſay they be vnfeithfull? or any trewth of vertue or honeſtee, when he ſaieth, they be abhominable? Therfore what is there in them, for the which they do ſo folowe them? any thing els, but (as I ſaid) deceuable wordes, a moſt vnworthy cauſe of folowing? And yet they folowe them neuertheleſſe. But why? Trewly there is none other why, but euen their own ignorāt & weiward wilfulnes: which doth alwai her ken & leane to a wrong ſpirite, directly ageinſt the wordꝭ of ſaint Iohn, where he ſaith,1. Ioan. 4 Nolite omni ſpiritui credere, ſed probate ſpiritus ſi ex deo ſint, do not geue credence (he ſaieth) to euery ſpirite, but proue the ſpirites whether thei be of god, whiche were ſoone proued in thoſe leaders, if theſe wordes of our ſauiour Chriſte, wer well and trewly weid of their folowers, where he ſaieth,Math. 7. ye ſhal know them by their fruictes: Wherfore although this were enough to him that had but halfe an eye, to ſee what manner of ſpirite thoſe leaders hath, yet becauſe we maie ſee with our whole eyes, that it ſinketh not, into ſuch mindes as their folowers hath, I wiſhe therfore, that they wolde but well behould, and conſider, this plaine and
manifeſt monition and warninge of ſaint paule, whiche he doth geue in this cace,Hebre. 13. where he ſeyth, Doctrinis variis et peregrinis nolite abduci, Take hede ye be not led a wey (he ſaieth) with diuerſe and ſtraynge doctrines: Marke, what doctrines he ſpeaketh of, diuerſe and ſtrainge he ſaith. And therfore the diuerſitee and ſtraingenes of their doctrines, conferred and conſidered with this leſſon of ſaint paule, me thinke ſhuld cauſe them to beware, not only of the oneſide what thei do, but alſo of the other ſide whom thei folow: for firſt ſo ſtrainge ther doctrines are, that thei thē ſelues can not tel, from whēce thei cam, nor whither thei wil: as it mai wel apere by this, that thei haue ſo often fayled & deceued thē ſelfes, in ther profe ther of: for where at the firſt, thei ſtifli ſaid, that thei came frō no les, thē out of ye holy ſcriptures, thei are therin founde moſt falſe & obſtinat liers, for the holi ſcriptures maketh clene ageinſt thē and wher, for a farder ſhift, thei ſeid (as ſomtime thei did) that thei came frō the olde holy doctors, therin thei lied as faſt agein of the other ſide, for thoſe holy fathers them ſelfes, do teſtify the contrari: and where thei had no farder to runne, but thē to ſay, that thei came from the primatiue church, the verie bokꝭ, of moſt godly writers in that holy time yet remaining, doth therin ſo cōuince their falſhed, that of ther lieng thei might be aſhamed. wherfore yet vnto this day, ſo ſtrange are ther doctrines euen to them ſelfes, that thei do not, only not know, from whence thei came, or whither thei will, but alſo that they are not ſo much as willing, to learne it nother: for when ſuch as doth perfitly know it in deede, doth daily tell them the trewth therof, thei will nother beleue them, nor yet ſo much, as quietly here them: Agein of the other ſide, as towching the diuerſitee of their doctrines, ſo diuerſe
we know thei be, that thei differ not only from the doctrine of the holy catholike church, (without the which there is no ſaluation) but alſo thei diffre, and not in a few thingꝭ, euen among them ſelues: as it may moſt plainly apere, by the ſondry and manifolde opinions, that reigneth among them: For wher ſo euer, one ſaieth one thing an other an other, as thei do in dede (the greate matter of the moſt holy ſacrament of the alter to witneſſe therof) There muſt nedꝭ be diuerſite of opinions: and wher ſo euer there is diuerſitee of opinions, (if it be, as this is, in matters of the faith) There muſt nedes be diuerſite of doctrines: And wher ſo euer ther is diuerſitee of doctrines, there muſte nedes be lacke of trewthe, (of one ſide, or other, or els of bothe together) And wher ſo euer there is lake of trewth, there the matter muſt nedes be ſtrainge, becauſe without trewth it can not be knowen: Wherfore by this it cummeth clerly to light, that the lacke of trewth is the very cauſe, of the great diuerſite and ſtrangeneſſe of their doctrines: for the helpe wherof, this only monition of holy ſeint paule, ſeying. Take hede ye be not ledde awaie, with diuerſe and ſtrainge doctrines, wer of it ſelf very ſufficient, wher enough were no leſſe then enough: But wher much more then enough, is nothing at al, what remedie, but pacience and pitee? Therfore what ſhall I ſay of thoſe their folowers, to whom all this will nothing ſerue? any thinge els, but that thei are becum the worthy partakers, of all the propre fructꝭ, that procedeth of the leaders? of the which fruictꝭ, let this very little of a great deale more and wors behinde, be now ſufficiente for this tyme.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Syr wot ye what?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: what.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: It chaunceth well that ye haue here vttered all this talke only betwene you & me: for if it had ben in writyng and openly knowne abrode, I dare well ſaie, it wolde haue diſpleaſed a great ſorte?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Why ſo.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: For two cauſes.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: What are thoſe?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: One is the hardeneſſe of the matter.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: What, whan it is but all in engliſhe?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Although it be. Yet many wolde thynke it harde to vnderſtande, for all that.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: That wolde none of our engliſh biblers dee, whiche ſticketh at nothynge in the holy ſcripture, wherin is moſt hardeneſſe of all.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Yet I am ſuer they wolde ſticke at this.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Than ſhulde they haue but a good occaſion therof, to lerne and ſee, how vninete they are, before they coulde well awaie with this, and other lyke, to goe to an other matter, of a thowſande folde more hardenes than this is of, as the holy ſcripture is in dede: wherfore the hardnes of this, coulde miniſter vnto them no cauſe of diſpleaſure at all, but rather the contrary: And therfore what other canſe is there els beſyde?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Without faile an other, far paſſyng this, and that is not the hardnes, but in dede the very matter it ſelfe.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: What cauleſt thou that?

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: The deſcripcion of the ſtate of an heretike.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: And wold that diſpleaſe ſo great a ſorte, as thou ſpeakeſt of?

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: Ye without doubte.

sp.speaker: CA.
sp.p:
Thou art therin clene deceiued: and I wyll tell the why. There is no man, that wil be diſpleaſed or greued, with the trew deſcripcion of an heretik, if he hym ſelfe, be not one of them in dede: wherfore, if it diſpleaſe not an heretike, it can diſplaſe no man: And an heretyke, it can not diſpleaſe nother, as it maie well apere
by this, that he can not beleue or thinke, that he is an heretike. And therfore he can not beleue or thinke, that this deſcripcion toucheth hym, any more than an other man: wherfore he can no more be greued with all, than an other man can.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Ough ſyr, neuer thinke ſo, for all they wolde yet coniecture and ſhrewdly ſuſpecte, that ye ment it of them, and of no men els.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: What, when thei can not ſo muche as thinke, that it doth any thynge touche them? There were no reaſon in that.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Syr, reaſon or reaſon not, ſo they wolde doe, for all that.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: As thou ſaieſt, we haue to muche experience of them already, to loke for any reſon, at their handes nowe: And yet becauſe of thy ſaiynge, I wiſſhe that this matter were in their heryng, to ſee how they wolde take it.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: full greuouſly I may ſaie to you.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p:
Then, other they wolde kepe their grefe ſecretly, or els they wold declare & ſhew it openly: if they wold kepe it ſecretly, it were their owne, and no mens els: If they wold declare it openly, they ſhuld but therin bewrey them ſelfes, and playnly ſhewe what they be: for if thou ſhuldeſt make a trewe generall deſcription of all felons or theues openly, and than, if any one of the audience, ſhould take it greuouſly, woldeſt thou not thinke, that he ſhulde therin, ſhewe hym ſelfe to be other one of ſuche a companie, or els at the leaſte a fauorer of that facultee, whiche in ſome reſpecte is wors then he? And therfore euen ſo lykewiſe it is, in this caſe of heretikes. For if thei wolde nedes herein, with the vtterance of their grefe, ſhewe them ſelfes, what they be: they muſt be content of the other ſide, that men ſhuld take them as thei be. For ſo men muſt nedes doe, without any remedy, becauſe no man can take a thyng otherwiſe, then he doth know it is.
Wherfore nowe to conclude, becauſe there is no diſeaſe of the body (being neuer ſo lamētable) that can be comparable to any mortall diſeaſe of the ſowie. And no mortall diſeaſe of the ſowle, can be cōparable to this pernicious plage of hereſie, I do therfore moſt hartely wiſh, that all men wold temper & qualifie, their conſideracions and remembrance therof, with ſuch earneſt pitee, & daily praier, as the miſerable ſtate of this vnfeithfull generacion doth of neceſſitee alwaie require: And therin to deſire, that it may pleaſe almighty god, not only ſo to ſtay thinfection therof, that it ſprede no farder: but alſo, with his great mercy & grace, ſo to viſet the hartes of ſuch as are infected and vexed with all, that they leſe not the profite of the time and ſpace, whiche to them he hath lent, therin to repent, & ſo to returne, to the ſwete pappes, of our moſt bleſſed mother, his holy catholike churche ageine. And therfore with this I bede the now farewell.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: Syr, ye will not ſerue me ſo?

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: Why, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: Where is that, which ye did promiſe, to ſpeake of frith?

sp.speaker: CA.
sp.p: Thou ſaidſt before, the daie was far ſpent. And now it appereth to be much more, for thou ſeeſt it is almoſt night: and therfore we haue now no tyme, to talke of ſo large a matter, as that wold be, if we ſhuld once enter in to it.

sp.speaker: HERE.
sp.p: Why ſir, it can not be longe for any faute ye can fynde in him, he beyng ſo honeſt a man, as I beleue he was.

sp.speaker: CATH.
sp.p: What ſo euer he was, in thy beleue, he was & is, in my knowlage, as ſubtill, falſe, and foliſh, as euer was any of his moſte wicked enterprice, that I haue other red or harde of.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: Sir in your ſo ſaiyng, ye do kindell my ſtomake, more thā ye are ware of.

sp.speaker: CA.
sp.p: What ſo euer I doe therin, I ſaie nothyng but trewth, which I am well able to proue.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p:
That profe
is it, that I wold here.

sp.speaker: CA.
sp.p: Thou knoweſt it can not be now.

sp.speaker: HE.
sp.p: when then?

sp.speaker: CA.
sp.p: when thou wilt thy ſelfe.

sp.speaker: HE.
sp.p: Then, that ſhall be euen to morow mornyng by fowre a clocke.

sp.speaker: CA.
sp.p: What ſofte and feire, thou art very ſwifte.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: I thinke it longe, I may tell to you.

sp.speaker: CA.
sp.p: So it ſemeth by thy haſt. but eight of the clocke is a faire owr.

sp.speaker: HE.
sp.p: Shall I not faile, to finde you here then?

sp.speaker: CA.
sp.p: If thou ſai the worde, thou ſhalt not only finde me here then, but alſo, that to be trew, which I haue now ſaid.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: what, that frith was ſubtill, falſe, and foliſhe?

sp.speaker: CA.
sp.p: Ye, as euer was any man.

sp.speaker: HE.
sp.p: Why, ſubtilte & foliſhnes, can not well ioyne together.

sp.speaker: CA.
sp.p: Yet, whether thei cā or no, he brought thē ſo nere together, that in his head, there was nothyng betwene them, but euen onely falſhed, whiche did knit vp the knot, of all his concluſiions.

sp.speaker: HE.
sp.p: O ſir I wold it wer mornyng as it is euenyng.

sp.speaker: CA.
sp.p: why so?

sp.speaker: HE.
sp.p: It greueth me to breake of, and to leue this matter thus.

sp.speaker: CA.
sp.p: Thou knoweſt the mornyng is not longe hence.

sp.speaker: HE.
sp.p: Well, ſith there is none other remedie, will ye remēber your owre ye ſpeake of?

sp.speaker: CA.
sp.p: double not therof.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: Then for my parte, I will not miſſe, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: CA.
sp.p: Therfore, god ſpede the well, for this time.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: And you alſo ſyr.
